[{'document_title': 'LAGOS AFFAIRS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We cannot say what may be the news now on its way to England from Lagos. We cannot defer the preparations for our paper until the day of its publication, and are therefore under the necessity of commenting on what is known to us at the time we write. We hope, and have reason to believe, that before our present number goes to press, we shall have received the long desired intelligence of the difficulties with Egbas, Jebus, and others being all removed; and of the long desolate markets of Lagos overflowing with produce. We have not any such news at present; but what we have, affords additional proof of the heavy responsibility that rests upon all concerned in the Government of a trading British settlement or colony, when they, through ignorance or malice, pursue a course which is calculated to bring on a commercial paralysis. By inexcusable ignorance on the part of a Secretary of State, and the very wantonness of official evil on the part of an Administrator, the trade and commerce of Lagos was arrested in its course on the 18th of March last. The authorities of the native interior countries from which Lagos draws its commercial supplies, had been goaded by repeated and incessant insults and wrongs, into a condition of mind which led them to refuse all further trading intercourse, until the official author of those insults and wrongs should be removed from the office which gave him power thus to outrage them and their people. At the first glance it would have seemed as if trade would be immediately resumed, from the moment such removal were made, and the obnoxious measures repealed and abolished; and we must confess that, although our knowledge of African thought and action is derived from the varied experience of many years, we fell into the error of believing that such would be the case in this instance. We thought the Egba authorities and the King of Jebu, knowing as they did that the grievances of which they had so much reason to complain were the unhealthy spawn of one diseased official mind alone—that the quarrel really was between them and the late Administrator of Lagos only, and not really between them and Great Britain, would have hastened to show their satisfaction at the removal of their official enemy from his post and power, and have at once set free the fettered hands of commerce. It has not been so. Captain Glover was sent away from Lagos by Mr. Pope Hennessey, on the 15th June—and all obnoxious decrees, irritating and injurious to the Egbas and others, were at the same time repealed; but yet, up to the 6th August at least, the Egbas and Jebus had not removed their interdict on trade. The venom was still rankling in the veins of those who had been stung, and a sense of offended dignity prevented the due consideration of the evils resulting to their own subjects and territories, as well as to Lagos and its traders, from the prohibition to export that produce on which the wealth and progress of both the one and the other depend. Lagos and its native traders and merchants especially have been thus doomed to a prolonged continuance of those evils to which we briefly alluded in our last; and in the paralysis of all available means for paying debts and obligations, the law—British law—has handed the unfortunate fish to the greedy cormorants who are ever ready to seek their unjust gains among the necessities of their fellow-men. British officials spear the fish—British magistrates net them—and British cormorants devour them. We feel it to be our duty, therefore, to repeat the protest we made in our last, against the uninterrupted action of commercial law, through British legal authorities and tribunals, at periods when the British governing power has chosen for its own ends, or in its own ignorance or wickedness, to cut off from the trading masses of the community, those means by which alone they could be enabled to meet their commercial engagements. During the perturbation caused by the late French and German war—during the siege of Paris, and the reign of the Commune, and for some time after, no creditor was allowed to put the machinery of law at work in France, for the enforcement of civil contracts, to despoil and ruin his fellow-citizen. And thus it ought to have been in Lagos during this suspension of trade, which resulted entirely from acts of Government, and not from any acts or errors of individual traders, or from any cause which any one individual of the trading community, or the whole body of them combined, could suspend or control. They did what they could by remonstrance, by petition, by communication to the Home authorities, and through the African Times; and having done this, they are none of them morally, however they may be made legally, responsible for the results against which they petitioned and remonstrated. We do not need any spirit to come from the other world to tell us that these remarks of ours will not produce the effects they ought to produce. The duty of a public writer is not limited by the extent of his power to procure the justice to which he may establish a claim. It is his duty to hold aloft the lamp of truth, and leave the results of his so doing to others. It is at least a consolation to victims, if the light thus diffused, shall enable every observer to see that the wheels which are crushing the poor victims of commercial misgovernment, are official ones; that they have not voluntarily thrown themselves under them with suicidal intent, but have been thrust under them by an erring Secretary of State, and the malicious wantonness of official power in his delegate, to whom the victim was bound to yield unresistingly. The light thus diffused may, and often does, serve also to prevent the recurrence of errors and wickedness of a similar kind, and thus gradually helps on changes which conduce to an enlarged general security against the errors and aberration of constituted authorities.', 'last_edit_date': '1872-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1872#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.68, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Local Press Mis-statements', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—I consider it due to the public to draw attention to the incorrect statements that appear in the three first issues of the _West African Herald_, under the present editor.

In his first issue (I shall take one instance only out of the numbers that appear in each paper) it is stated that the Fantis, although numbering 70,000 against 12,000 Ashantis, had been defeated by the enemy. The Fantis never had 70,000 men in the field, and the enemy had nearly four times the number given him.

In the second issue, it is stated in a letter addressed by the editor to our present Administrator-in-Chief, that the King of Denkira complained of the conduct of the Government Interpreter, Mr. James Davis, and that the king had no confidence in Mr. Davis. I am in a position to assert that Acquessi Kaye, the King of Denkira, told the Administrator-in-Chief that he had never authorized any such statement, and that he had the greatest confidence in Mr. Davis.

In the third issue, it is stated that the king and chiefs, at their meeting with his Excellency on the 7th June last, said that, owing to their cowardice, they were unable to fight the Ashantis. I have made inquiries from parties who were present at the meeting—kings, chiefs, and others—and they assure me that they made no use of any such expression.

It is always an unpleasant task to be compelled to draw attention to mis-statements; but history cannot be truly written unless this duty, however unpleasant, is performed.—I am, Sir,', 'last_edit_date': '1873-06-30', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_08_1873#article-25', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.683, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'TRUE STATEMENTS OF THE CAUSE OF LAGOS DISASTERS.—No. I.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "We in Lagos don't thank Mr. Clare and his friends for all their gross misrepresentations which, we feel sure, Mr. Clare will himself be sorry for when his eyes shall be opened to the truth. These are all matters of bargain, and trade, and gain, caused by what the natives call ofu kokoro—i.e., covetous eyes. Those who have been accustomed to feast on the Lagos revenue still set their eyes upon it, and therefore desire and labour hard to get the Captain back, that the squandering may go on to their benefit. Whatever may be said of Governor Pope Hennessy, he has done well during his short administration. Whatever may be his creed, it was not he who caused the roads to be closed. Mr. Editor, does Mr. Clare never read the African Times, especially since 1871? If he had done so, he would have escaped being misled as he has been; unless it be that the Manchester loan business has unconsciously blinded his eyes to facts.

Mr. Editor, please publish all these facts for the information of Lord Kimberley, Mr. Hugessen, and other authorities in Downing-street, and also for all the Members of Parliament during their session, so that they may be able to refute Mr. Jacob Bright for Chas. Leigh Clare and Co., and all the clique of the Gloverians.

We hope, ere this reaches you, the roads will be opened. The people are, we think, perfectly satisfied now, that Captain Glover is not coming out again.—Your obedient servant,", 'last_edit_date': '1873-03-13', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_04_1873#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.682, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE "AFRICAN TIMES" AND THE AUTHORITIES AT LAGOS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We find that complaint is made at Lagos of the article in our February number, relative to the non-delivery in Lagos of our journal of the 23rd November. We are accused of undue and intemperate haste in charging any of the colonial authorities with the suppression of our paper on that occasion, and condemned for writing as if there was a certainty about it, when there not only was no certainty at all, but, moreover, when the thing really had not taken place. We are told we ought to have waited, and made proper inquiry, and then we should have found there was no truth whatever in the statement. We do not think we were unduly hasty. We did not act upon a single testimony. We received letters from several of our subscribers complaining of the alleged fact; and it was, we believe, the first time such a thing had occurred; and there did happen to be in the November number, also for the first time, certain matter which might not be quite agreeable to the authorities. The papers had been duly
**125**

posted in England, and the papers were not duly delivered in Lagos. We were therefore justified in writing on the supposition that they had been purposely withheld from our subscribers. And what is now the explanation we have indirectly received? "The greater portion of the November number of the 'African Times' arrived in December, and the two numbers for November and December were delivered together to the various subscribers," i.e., we presume, if words mean anything, that the November papers which arrived in Lagos in December, were detained at the Post-office there until the December papers arrived in January, and then the papers of the two months were delivered to the subscribers at the same time. We can only say in reply that under such circumstances our subscribers who did not receive the November papers in December were fully justified in believing that they had been suppressed, and in writing to us to that effect. In order to avoid the recurrence of similar unfounded charges against any of the Lagos authorities, we therefore beg respectfully to suggest that they will do well at all times to deliver the papers immediately on their arrival.', 'last_edit_date': '1866-05-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1866#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.71, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'LETTERS TO THE EDITOR', 'section_title': '', 'content': '(The Editor cannot hold himself responsible for the opinions of his correspondents.)*

---

### DISSATISFACTION AMONG THE NATIVES IN LAGOS.

**TO THE EDITOR OF THE "AFRICAN TIMES."**

December 18, 1884.

Sir,—Your journal being the representative organ in Europe for the West Coast of Africa, we feel compelled to state, for the information of the authorities in Downing-street and the public generally, that up to the embarkation in August last of Commander Rumsey, the Deputy Governor of Lagos, for Europe, the town was quiet; but since then there has been general dissatisfaction, owing to several "acts" of the present Administration, whose advisers have managed to create dissensions, and to set class against class. Acting under cover of authority, respectable natives have been arrested on pain of being locked up in the guard-room of the Houssas, or seized and deported to St. Helena, without any real cause, while the accused is kept ignorant of his offence. Such, Sir, are the acts of certain officials (European and native) in Lagos, who design to gain popularity, honour, and promotion by misrepresentations. The administrations of Sir Samuel Rowe, Lieut.-Governor Griffith, Captain Moloney, and Captain Rumsey are disparaged by these men. We ask, can a servant be greater than his master? These men say they know Lagos and Africa more than any other person. But what knowledge can be looked for from men whose previous lives have been all unfitted for such duties as they now have to perform? It is honourable to rise from humble positions; yet the mind should be humble; and when uncultivated, to give such persons positions is dangerous. Is it customary for the Premier of England, or the Secretary of State for the Colonies, to send a policeman from their official residence in Downing-street to arrest any of the members of the Opposition simply on the report that they speak against the Government, and on their arrival in Downing-street to abuse and insult them, and ultimately send them to prison forthwith, or exile to Canada, saying that the official powers are extraordinary and unlimited? We ask, is this possible? and would such action show a cultivated mind and civility? It is an open secret in Lagos that such treatment is by no means uncommon here.

It is a blessing that we are under a Governor-in-Chief who is well able to check the ambitious views of his subordinates.

Is it usual for the Premier of England or Governor of a colony to send a superintendent of police with one or two constables to proclaim, without law or ordinance, that no provisions are to be sold to a neighbouring friendly country; and if such country retaliate by stopping its own supply, then for the sovereign of the friendly country to be accused as a barbarous and atrocious king?—Your obedient servants,

**LAGOSIANS.**', 'last_edit_date': '1885-02-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_02_1885#article-28', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.678, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE "LAGOS TIMES."', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We hail with pleasure the appearance of a new local West African Journal, published at Lagos, under the title of the Lagos Times. Two numbers of this new fortnightly periodical have reached us, and we have felt very great satisfaction in perusing their contents. The second number has an editorial on the unpardonable official error committed in the despatch of Mr. Thomas Tickel on a political mission to Abeokuta, without any previous communication with the Egba Government, to inform them of the object and scope of the proposed mission, and obtain their consent to receive Mr. Tickel as an accredited political agent of the Lagos Executive. As the editor in his very able and moderate leader has stated, it ought to have been perfectly well known to those having the conduct of the public affairs of the colony that a mission thus dispatched would be certain to offend the just susceptibilities of a Native Government that in its relation with Lagos since it became a British colony has always stood upon its dignity and independence, and refused to abate one jot or tittle of its claims to respect. That settlement has been so great a sufferer through official mismanagement, and so many innocent persons have, as a consequence, been wholly or in part ruined, with a serious loss thereby of British capital, that the wounds require soothing by anodynes, not irritating by caustic. During the interview of the commercial deputation with Earl Kimberley in May last, his lordship spoke so confidently as to the merits of Captain Strachan, who might be regarded "as almost a civilian," that we expected to hear of a courteous, confidence-inspiring Administrator installed in his person within the walls of the Government-house at Lagos. We regret, however, that it should be our duty to state that the first impressions at Lagos have not been favourable as regards the new Administrator. If the description came to us from one quarter only, we should have taken no public notice of it; but it comes to us from several and distinct ones; and what we gather is, that his tone is not at all a soothing one; his bearing is lofty, for Africa, and frightens even Europeans away from Government-house. We cannot help feeling that this is a bad beginning. His predecessor, Mr. Berkeley, the present Governor-in-Chief of the West Coast Settlements, gained golden opinions of all in Lagos; he was beloved there; and we never heard that the public service was thereby injured, or the Queen's government thereby lowered in the estimation of Europeans or natives. It would be, indeed, lamentable should Colonel Strachan undo what Mr. Berkeley effected; nor do we hesitate to say that such a result would put an end at once and for ever to the system of appointing naval and military men as Administrators of commercial settlements—a system which was, with so much reason, denounced by the deputation, to whose interview with Earl Kimberley we have before alluded.', 'last_edit_date': '1873-11-29', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_11_1873#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.689, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At the present time, from all parts of the West African coast, we have reports of troubles and disturbances, which must hamper trade and retard the commercial and civilising development of that part of the Dark Continent. For some months now the trade of Lagos has been blocked by the closing of the roads which, running through the district inhabited by the Jebu and Egba tribes, connect that port with the interior; but we are pleased to learn, from the latest telegrams received, that the careful and earnest steps that are being taken by the authorities to secure the opening of these trade routes, have not been without their moral effect upon the tribes implicated, for they are already making overtures of peace and reconciliation. It is much to be hoped that this is the case, for at the present time trade needs fostering on the West Coast more than perhaps ever before, and this object can only be attained by the cheerful co-operation of all interested in its maintenance. The British administration in West Africa has been by no means free from faults in the past; and these faults have born their natural fruit. The secret of good Colonial government would seem to consist in interfering as little as possible with Native customs and prejudices, but at the same time making it thoroughly understood that laws and ordinances must be respected. Now that the dispute with the Jebus and Egbas would seem to be in a fair way of settlement, it affords an opportunity to the Governor of Lagos to insure that, though these tribes are to be treated fairly and with patience, they must quite understand that any infraction of the engagements now or subsequently undertaken by them, will be visited most severely upon the offenders.

Encouraged by your impartiality in giving publicity to any communications of the kind, I have taken up my pen to solicit your inserting this letter in your columns, in order to give some explanation about the Ikorodu affair, of which you have been misinformed.

Since that affair has taken place there is no one that reads the communications sent to your paper from Lagos month after month who will not arrive at the conclusion to which you have come—viz., justifying the Governor of Lagos in his proceedings towards Abeokuta. You will remember that after he had accomplished his "well-known policy" he prevents all communications from this place reaching England, thereby preventing any other account being circulated. If criticism never conquers truth, why did he put such a restriction on us?

Let me also inform you that the opening of the road to Ikorodu was not the object for which the Ibadans and the Abeokutans had been engaged in war, nor was that the cause that induced the Governor to carry an expedition against the Abeokutans, as the following narration of facts will serve to show:—', 'last_edit_date': '1865-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1865#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.678, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Notes from the Gambia', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Our resident correspondent at the Gambia, under date Sept. 14th, sends us the following notes with reference to the present condition of affairs in the settlement:—

"After being long overdue, the s.s. Lagos has just put in her appearance, instead of the s.s. Senegal which was expected. Trade was never in such a ruinous condition as it is at present, and things in general are bearing an ominous look with regard to the prospects of the approaching trade season. Already some mercantile houses, both English and French, are reducing their staffs of European clerks, and in some cases the legal notice is being given to employés throughout the establishment. It is reported that we shall ere long miss the present Administrator for the more lucrative post at the Gold Coast, and should the report be confirmed, the Gambia will have lost one of her best Administrators, who, while courteous to all, is equally strict, in point of business, to all his officers alike, without regard to colour or class. Just now investigations are being carried on in connexion with the Colonial Hospital, where a sick man was taken for treatment, and accordingly reported to the Colonial Surgeon; the poor man died without having been seen by the Colonial Surgeon, though it is reported he had knowledge of the circumstance prior to the man's death. There is nothing new in this, and some more serious cases could be reported if an official inquiry is called for in respect to the treatment of patients at the Colonial Hospital; the public has not yet forgotten the painful circumstances attending the death of Emanuel Johns and others, on whom inquests have been held.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-11-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_11_1885#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.677, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH MISRULE IN WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Under this heading there has lately appeared in the London Daily Graphic a series of illustrated articles, tending to show how demoralizing to the Native mind is much that arises from the present system of British rule and influence in this part of the world. It is now more than a century since Sierra Leone was founded, to be a centre of light and civilisation for the whole West Coast of Africa; and it must be admitted by every one who has made a study of this matter, that so far this purpose has not been achieved. When we look to India and Australia we are struck with wonder at the marvellous material and moral progress which is the outcome of a century of British rule. But with Africa—the West Coast especially—the result is far different; in spite of the great extension of European influence in that portion of the world, it is doubtful whether the Native, quâ Native, is really the better for what has been brought before him during the last hundred years. Not that it is his fault; at least, entirely. When Great Britain set herself to the task of redeeming the great debt which she, above all nations, owed to Africa—for was not she the originator of the shameful Slave Trade?—she was prompted doubtless by the best of motives, but did not fully appreciate the difficulties of the task she then undertook. To repair the wrong she herself had inflicted there was but one sure course—to devote her best. The history of the past century is one long catalogue of failures in this respect, and the result is made manifest now, when we see the Native West African brought down by the drink traffic to a level lower than that of those who have not been affected by the so-called civilisation.

Speaking of the demoralizing effect of the unchecked drink traffic, Mr. F. Buxton, in the Daily Graphic, draws a sharp contrast between the present moral and social state of the Natives in the French colony of the Gaboon and what he saw at Freetown. "Freetown, with its hills rising behind it, forms a pretty picture from the bay where ships lie at anchor, but the town itself is fairer to behold from a distance than pleasant to inspect closely. This is a subject of great importance, especially when it is considered that it must be mainly owing to the exertions of a police, under judicious and well-defined regulations, that crimes can be brought to the notice of the authorities and punished. In the absence of such regulations, the name and office of police are mere mockeries. We deeply regret, then, to state that, literally speaking, there is not a single written rule for the guidance of the Lagos police. Some time in 1869 a few directions were put in writing by the then Superintendent, but it is believed these were mere private memoranda for his own guidance, for they were neither signed by him nor sanctioned by the then Administrator; consequently, the succeeding Superintendents have never been able safely to use them as official. Further, not even when peculiar exigencies in the colony need special rules for their treatment, do the police have these supplied to them. This state of things greatly hinders the efficient working of the police scheme in Lagos, and has many a time put matters in great confusion—e.g., when your October issue appeared with a letter condemning the apathy of the Lagos Government on the question of domestic slavery in Lagos, carried on under the Administrator's very nose, general orders were issued from Government House for the police to be on the alert to bring slave-dealers to justice. There being no special rule as to how this was to be done, or on what grounds the police were to apprehend people, or how they were to prosecute them, and nine-tenths of them being illiterate men, great confusion took place. The Administrator himself was at a loss how to manage to get certain arrested parties convicted, without incurring the displeasure of his friend and confidante, Chief (?) Taiwo; and the Acting Stipendiary Magistrate (Mr. C. D. Turton) and the Superintendent of Police were threatened by one Monsieur Callamand with a law-suit if they did not prove against him the charge of slave-dealing, for which he had been summoned to the Police-court. All these things prove the absolute necessity there exists for established rules to guide the police in their action; for, had there been such, his Excellency would have known at once how to have acted in the matter, instead of sending for remanded prisoners from the House of Correction, and assembling them before Chief (?) Taiwo, to tell them they were free. The Superintendent of Police, too, did not know what he was taking a summons against Callamand for; hence he narrowly escaped having a law-suit about his ears. Moreover, this state of things lessens the authority of the police, and renders nearly abortive their exertions to maintain ordinary peace; for when once the people of Lagos think that Taiwo's influence with Mr. Dumaresq is sufficient to free them from the hands of the police, there is no knowing what amount of mischief they will do. But for the African Times, we say,—but for your able leader in the November issue on the subject of Lagos slave-dealers, at this time there would be seen about in the streets of Lagos slave-dealers asking those they meet, "You want buy man?" You see, Mr. Editor, the good the African Times is doing here for us. We thank God for its existence; we hope, also, that you will long live (never despairing) to edit and issue the African Times, bringing to light those monstrous evils perpetrated about our coast.', 'last_edit_date': '1877-01-18', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1877#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.68, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'FALSE WEIGHTS AND MEASURES', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—Lagos was ceded to the Crown a very long time ago, and it is time now to check the wrongs which are being done in this Settlement. Many of the merchants, as well as the traders, are doing wrong to the public by cheating them through adding a piece of lead on their scale. In the whole Settlement we have no proper scale or measuring yard. Every grog or rum seller makes his own gill to sell with; a glass of rum will not fill a table spoon; and we have three-quarters of a yard of cloth for thirty-six inches, which makes one yard. In the meantime we have about three inspectors of police by name, but not on duty. We will be very glad, Mr. Editor, if our Administrator will take notice, and try to put down such evils in this Settlement. A false balance is an abomination to the Lord: a dishonest tradesman here receives a hard stroke. Though his weight be but little short of the standard, yet by using it a thousand times the fraud becomes greater and greater still, as it falls chiefly on the poor.—Yours, &c.,', 'last_edit_date': '1878-10-26', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_12_1878#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.685, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE MAILS TO THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '_The Standard_, of December 27, has the following:—

_To the Editor of the Standard._

Sir,—As you are always so ready to advocate the cause of the aggrieved, can you or any of your correspondents inform me and my fellow-shippers how and when the mails for the West Coast of Africa go and come, the contract for carrying them by the African Steamship Company having, it appears, expired. We are now at the mercy of the British and African Company, and I should imagine Government arrangements with them are far from satisfactory; insomuch that the only announcement at the Post-office is that letters will be dispatched "as opportunity offers," and upon application there a day or two since, the clerk who applied was informed that no one could tell when the next mail would be. Before the contract with the African Steamship Company expired, it was no uncommon thing for the mail from Sierra Leone, an eighteen-days' mail, to arrive six and eight days overdue. This was bad enough, considering how we may anticipate letters from Australia, China, or the Brazils to the day—but now not even to know when to look for letters, or, what is worse, to be in total darkness as to when the mails are dispatched hence, it appears monstrous. Our trading relations with Sierra Leone are considerably on the increase, and to have such an effectual check as this placed on our transactions with our friends in that colony, really seems too bad.—Yours truly,

_A Perplexed Merchant._

December 24.

Niger Mission—A Warning to Native Merchants', 'section_title': '', 'content': '## A WARNING TO NATIVE MERCHANTS.

### TO THE EDITOR OF "THE AFRICAN TIMES."

Sir,—Will you permit me space in your pages to show some of my brethren on the West Coast how I have been swindled by a firm of professing merchants in London, in the hope that a relation of my experience may be of service to others, and cause them to make all needful inquiries as to the good faith and solvency of those to whom they are thinking of consigning goods for realisation in the London markets, or money for purchase of goods for Africa.

In May last year I received letters from a firm dating from the City, offering to do business with me, whether in the way of realisation or purchase, and professing to have exceptional facilities for the disposal of African produce, and the purchase of European goods in exchange. They made such a plausible tale that I was quite taken with them, and forwarded a box of gold dust, together with samples of goods I wanted in return. This came duly into their hands, and I received an acknowledgment from them with a statement showing that the gold dust had realised £56 10s. 10d., but that the goods I required would cost a good deal more than that. I accordingly obtained and forwarded to them a draft, making in all £97 10s. 2d.; at the same time sending them my gold watch (value £7) for cleaning and repairs in London. This second remittance was also acknowledged in due course—and there the matter ended! Finding weeks go by, and nothing come to hand, I wrote to a firm in London, upon whose integrity I can rely, for them to inquire into the matter, and do the best they could—either in the way of getting back my money or by urging these people to hurry on with the goods, so that I might not entirely lose the market. They accordingly wrote to the firm in question several times, but only to receive vague promises of immediate attention, or still more evasive answers. So I determined myself to come to London to see what could be done. And the upshot of my inquiries is that the firm to whom I had consigned my money and goods have proved utter swindlers: they traded under a fancy name, and when they found things were getting too hot for them they left the country, so as to be beyond the reach of the law.

For myself I must make up my mind to cut my loss; as I understand that even if I could get hold of the swindlers there is no chance of my regaining any portion of what they have had from me. But I hope my experience will be of some use to others who, trading on the West Coast of Africa, are under the necessity of trusting so much to persons or firms in London or the other European capitals.—Yours faithfully,', 'last_edit_date': '1891-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1891#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.681, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: Colonial governance in Africa was marked by ineffective administration and abuse of power, leading to exploitation and social issues due to unfit officials and lack of accountability.
result: The General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles collectively provide a comprehensive view supporting the claim that colonial governance in Africa was marked by ineffective administration and abuse of power, leading to exploitation and social issues. The textbook highlights the manipulation and weakening of indigenous systems of government, where colonial powers often deposed traditional rulers, appointed unqualified chiefs, and used them to enforce unpopular measures like forced labor and taxes. This resulted in a loss of prestige and authority for traditional leaders, sparking revolts and rebellions. The colonial system was authoritarian and paternalistic, with limited political representation for Africans, as seen in places like Algeria and South Africa. The imposition of taxes and forced labor exemplified the exploitative nature of colonial rule, causing malnutrition, famine, and social dislocation, while racial discrimination and humiliation contributed to social issues and a sense of inferiority. Similarly, The African Times articles highlight instances of exploitation and social issues due to unfit officials and a lack of accountability. They report on British authorities' failure to address theft effectively, misuse of police powers in Lagos, and mismanagement of resources, such as the excessive costs of civil administration in Freetown and inefficiency of the colonial hospital in the Gambia. The articles also criticize colonial officials' conduct, including excessive drinking and abuse in Accra, and the flogging and torture of natives on the Gold Coast. These examples illustrate pervasive issues of misrule, corruption, and neglect within the colonial administration. However, the articles also note efforts to address some issues, such as the Consul's attempts to mediate disputes and improve the Egbo Institution, indicating that not all colonial actions were entirely negative. Together, these sources provide a detailed account of the challenges and failures of colonial governance in Africa, underscoring the widespread administrative inefficiency and exploitation.

Even when they emphasized 'native paramountcy', they did so with the thought that the welfare of the African populations could only be guaranteed and effectively structured socially and economically by them. Good government and independent government were, as Lord Cromer once remarked, opposing objectives in a colonial context. Thus the colonial system existed as an authoritarian one, and it was in no meaningful way calculated to confer political power upon the Africans it supposedly served. Its most common characteristic was paternalism, with shared responsibility at best only tolerated in areas of considerable white settlement. The history of the changing purposes and interpretation of 'native paramountcy' in Kenya is instructive in this matter. The White Paper of 1923 employed the concept as a device by which to stave off the demands of the Indian population for equitable representation in the affairs of the colony. Subsequent White Papers issued in 1927 and 1930 qualified the concept and contained concessions to the growing white residential population which was now allowed to join in the responsibilities of'trusteeship'. Native paramountcy therefore did not really imply dominance of African interests, but only respect for them.\nEven where parliamentary institutions were introduced to provide a degree of responsible colonial government, this arrangement was effected so that white preponderance was guaranteed. The Repre› sentation of Natives Act of 1936 effectively removed the Africans from the Cape Colony electoral rolls and limited their political status throughout the Union to the election of a limited number of whites who were to represent 'native interests'. In these two major settler colonies, exactly as in all the other colonies in which residential Europeans were to be found, the demographic minority was in fact the political majority, thus precluding any resemblance to democratic government on the European model.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.645, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Politics and nationalism in Central and Southern Africa, 1919-35', 'section_title': 'The economic and political setting in Angola and Mozambique: an overview > Popular opposition to colonial rule in Mozambique', 'content': "Africano (The African Voice), pursued a similar objective as the self-defined guardian of African peasants and workers. On the occasion of its seventh anniversary, O Brado Africano proudly proclaimed that 'the Africans have in Brado Africano their best defense, indeed, their only weapon against the injustices which fall upon them. 104 In their news stories and commentaries both journals highlighted four recurring abuses chíbalo, the poor working conditions of free African labour, the preferential treatment given to white immigrants, and the lack of educational opportunities - which to the editors symbolized the very essence of colonial oppression. [{'id': 397, 'article_title': 'ACCRA', 'full_section_title': 'ACCRA', 'last_edit_date': '06-11-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_07_1864#article-8', 'issue_date': '23_07_1864', 'content': 'I wrote you by last mail about the case of an Aungla man who had stolen some rum and a canoe. The advice given by the King of the Aunglas, that the British authorities should seize Aungla people, was of course not acted upon by Captain Edmunds. But I am sorry also to say that the case was treated as one of ordinary theft, according to the regular routine, in which the plaintiff should have paid for a second summons—some twenty shillings and upward—that a constable might be again sent beyond the Volta. This he declined to do, as he considered one summons quite sufficient, and thought that it was the duty of the Chief Civil Commandant either to settle the case upon one summons, or to give him his summons money back again. The fact is, that our authorities have no power whatever beyond the river Volta, since they have withdrawn their soldiers from the fort at Quittah; and therefore I must state my opinion, that it is wrong to accept summons money for cases which they are not able to settle. It is even a question whether Mr. Cuthbert did right to fine the man for seizing Aungla people, being, as he was, unable to help him to get his property back. It is all very well to assert that panyaring is not right, and will not be allowed, but then you must be able to help your subjects effectually, if you will not allow them to help themselves. Of course, I do not justify the man, either in buying rum or in panyaring people; but if our Government is weak—and it is weak—boasting at Accra is of no use, and does not bring much credit upon the authorities.

As your valuable paper is not only written for the Africans, but also to enlighten the "mother country," and as it seems that you get very little information about that large country which lies between the river Volta and Dahomey, I will endeavour to give you some news. First, I must say that, as in Aungla and over the long track of land to Whydah they are doing very little beyond buying slaves, the people in the interior are manstealers to a great extent. I have some letters before me, written by schoolboys in a mission-school of the Slave Coast, in which they try to give a sort of description of their earlier life. I will translate one or two:—

1. Henry says: "My home is Agu, where I was born about twelve years ago. I was with my parents more than seven years; I loved them, and they loved me too. But one day, when I was playing on the market-place, a stranger came, took me into his arms, and carried me away. I cried, but nobody came to help me; and after marching twelve days, I was brought to Anyako," &c., &c.'}, {'id': 566, 'article_title': 'Lord Stanley on the Motion for a Special Committee (Western Africa)', 'full_section_title': 'Lord Stanley on the Motion for a Special Committee (Western Africa)', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_03_1865#article-12', 'issue_date': '23_03_1865', 'content': "Again, we must express our deep regret at but too much of what Lord Stanley thought and uttered. The liability to expensive wars—the very inferior Government agents employed—the absence of any healthy controlling public opinion which might act as a check upon the vices and general conduct of officials and other Europeans—are indeed serious matters, and well deserving the attentive consideration of the House of Commons."}, {'id': 3283, 'article_title': 'THE SLAVE-TRADE IN LAGOS: EFFECT PRODUCED BY LETTER IN THE AFRICAN TIMES (OCTOBER).', 'full_section_title': 'THE SLAVE-TRADE IN LAGOS: EFFECT PRODUCED BY LETTER IN THE AFRICAN TIMES (OCTOBER).', 'last_edit_date': '11-10-1876', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1877#article-9', 'issue_date': '01_01_1877', 'content': 'Dear Sir,—Touched to the quick by the grave evil into which our authorities have fallen in dealing with that all-important subject about which you took the trouble to publish my poor letter in your October number, and being humbly sure of your philanthropic indulgence and assistance to every friend of truth, freedom, and justice, and, according to your paper's motto, to every colonist who suffers from injustice, your humble servant cannot help but importune you so soon, in order that you may kindly strike while the "iron is hot," call the attention of Downing-street, and every Africa's friend in England and elsewhere, to this "dire eclipse," and use the means you may think proper in demolishing this stronghold of our antagonist, the devil.'}, {'id': 3771, 'article_title': 'Important Proceedings at Old Calabar', 'full_section_title': 'Important Proceedings at Old Calabar', 'last_edit_date': '01-01-1879', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1879#article-11', 'issue_date': '01_04_1879', 'content': 'There had been a long-standing and very intricate palaver, or rather series of palavers, between Duke Town and Henshaw Town. It required an immense amount of patience, tact, and energy to enable any one to see through all the ins and outs of the various points of contention. However, the Consul seemed to master all, and he was able to present such a basis of agreement as was readily accepted by both parties. There was a hand-shaking and an interchange of civilities such as had not taken place between the parties for years. May the reconciliation and peace be permanent!

I enclose a printed copy of the "Agreement" entered into between the Consul and the Duke Town authorities.

It is worthy of record that the Consul occupied the pulpit of Duke Town Church one Sabbath afternoon, and delivered (of course, through an interpreter) a very good, plain, practical discourse to a very crowded native audience.

One of the worst features of the Egbo Institution has all along been the licence given to the Egbo runners to flog and otherwise abuse any person whom they might fall in with who had not bought the privileges of the particular grade of the Institution represented by the runners in possession of the town. A strong effort was made to get that iniquitous abuse abolished. All, however, that the Consul could wring out of the authorities on this point was a verbal promise that henceforth due intimation shall be given to the whole town, by the ringing of the big Egbo bell to give warning that the runners will be out; and, further, that the runners themselves shall always give notice of their approach by sounding the bell attached to their persons. This is a step in the right direction, but it does not strike at the root of the evil. So far back as 1856, the Earl of Clarendon, then H.M.'s Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, instructed the then Consul (Hutchinson), in his dealings with the native chiefs, "to insist strongly, in the name of H.M.'s Government, on the discontinuance of the barbarous custom" referred to.

Both traders and missionaries testified their approval of the procedure of the Consul by presenting to him written addresses after his more important public work was over. That of the missionaries is rather long perhaps, but I shall furnish you with a few extracts from it. That of the traders breathed the same spirit of cordial approval of what the Consul had accomplished.

The missionaries in their address write thus:—

"It was with much satisfaction that we learned six or eight months ago of your appointment to the Consulate of the Bights of Biafra and Benin. You have not come among us as a stranger. We 'knew the man and his communications; and from what we saw of you when, years ago, you sojourned among us for a time, we cherished high expectations in reference to your discharge of your official duties, and we have not been disappointed. . . .'}, {'id': 6075, 'article_title': 'CHARTERED COMPANIES IN AFRICA.', 'full_section_title': 'CHARTERED COMPANIES IN AFRICA.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_03_1891#article-0', 'issue_date': '02_03_1891', 'content': 'If the responsibility upon those who accept the powers granted them by charter is great, still greater is the responsibility upon those who advise the grant. Firstly, they must consider the general principles of the control which the Government must exercise, and the points to which their attention should be directed in the exercise of this control; secondly, they must consider the manner in which this control must be exercised; thirdly, they must be careful in their selection of the persons to whom they entrust the exercise of this control; and, fourthly, they must be especially careful as to those to whom they entrust the powers conferred by any charter; for, however perfect may be the control which they exercise, if these powers are granted to improper or unfit persons, they are certain to be wrongly used. The responsibility of a Government is in no way lessened, but rather increased, when they devolve any of their powers to a company, one of whose objects is the obtaining of pecuniary profits; and this is accentuated in the case where those placed under the jurisdiction of such a company are imperfectly civilised, and lacking in means by which those governed have the power of making known and removing the grievances under which they suffer.

Another responsibility which rests upon the Government which grants a charter to any among its subjects, is that of preventing them from using those privileges in such a manner as to conflict with the rights of their fellow-subjects, or so as to involve the commonwealth in political difficulties with other countries.

Those who accept the charter have a heavy responsibility as well as those that grant it, and in this responsibility every owner partakes. Men may of their own free will, and for many reasons, abstain from exercising their political rights in their own country: in most cases they become possessed of those rights without any exertion on their own part, and if they do exercise them, do not do so for pecuniary profit. Every individual who invests in the shares of a chartered company does so of his own free will, and presumably with the hope of profit; that they should profit by their spirit of enterprise, and by the employment of their capital, is right, but in so doing they accept the position of being rulers over their fellow-men, and are responsible for any wrong which may be done to them. The native races, who are placed under the rule of a chartered company, are in a different position from the servants of a railway or other industrial company; they are placed under a rule and laws without being consulted, and have no means of escaping from the effects of that rule and of those laws.'}, {'id': 6853, 'article_title': 'Liverpool and the African Trade', 'full_section_title': 'Liverpool and the African Trade', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/05_05_1897#article-6', 'issue_date': '05_05_1897', 'content': '

**THE TRIAL OF DR. PETERS,** a brief _résumé_ of which we give on another page, is but unpleasant reading for those optimists who look for immediate advantage to Africa and her people from the recent great spread of Colonial enterprise on the part of the chief European nations. Dr. Peters was the representative of German Imperial authority within the limits of what is known as German East Africa, and as such he was entrusted with extraordinary powers, including that of life and death over the Natives, within the limits of his jurisdiction. It stands to reason that the authority he thus wielded was conferred upon him solely for the furtherance of civilisation, and the enforcement of submission to the laws promulgated by the central authority in Berlin; but Dr. Peters stands convicted on the clearest possible evidence of having taken advantage of his official position to further his own private ends, and to wreak his vengeance upon certain of the Natives who had offended him in a manner that was devoid of all legality, and only calculated to bring German authority in his district into contempt and loathing. No doubt one great difficulty in the way of steadily building up a prosperous and respected Colonial government, in a region so far removed from the centre of administrative authority, is the fact that it is necessary to entrust in the hands of one man such immense powers as are not granted in districts more readily subject to official oversight without being safeguarded in a way that is not possible in these more remote situations; and the temptation that such official is under to forget the purpose for which this immense authority is delegated to him, and to put in force his supreme powers to accomplish a purpose for which they were never intended. The Germans seem to have been particularly unfortunate in the persons to whom this great trust has been committed—witness the case of Herr Last in the Cameroons, and now that of Dr. Peters in the East. It cannot be said that the punishment meted out in either of these cases partakes of the demerit of undue severity; no doubt the disgrace of Dr. Peters in being so ignominiously dismissed from the Imperial service, judged from a purely moral standpoint, is heavy enough; but a man proved guilty of such abominable cruelty to Natives who were entrusted to his keeping would not receive much sympathy even if some of that material punishment were meted out to him which he showed himself so ready to inflict upon others. At the same time great credit is due to the Berlin authorities for the readiness they have shown, in both these cases, in bringing to trial, and subsequent conviction and punishment, even their highest colonial officials, for such gross perversion of the powers entrusted to them for the benefit of those under them and the credit of the German Empire; and we can only hope that these proceedings will serve as a warning to other European officials in barbarous and semi-civilised districts, and cause them to be more careful in the future as to their conduct towards those committed to their charge, seeing that punishment, "though she moves with a club foot," will overtake them sooner or later.'}]
