tat_extra: [{'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Upon another page our readers will find the text of a letter which has been addressed by the members of the African Trade Section of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce to Lord Salisbury, as Foreign Secretary, upon the subject of the boundaries of the territories of the Royal Niger Company in the Oil Rivers Districts. As is perhaps only natural, the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce strongly protested against the extension of the authority of the Royal Niger Company over any portion of the Oil Rivers, and they point out that only two years ago the grant of a Royal Charter was refused to this very district. No doubt the presence of a large trading company, endued with special and exceptional powers, has a tendency to dwarf other commercial undertakings in the same district. But the Government are necessarily swayed by broader considerations than the advantage or disadvantage of certain individual traders. Their chief object is to provide for the administration of the particular district. The existence of chartered companies is only tolerable in uncivilised or semi-civilised countries, where the presence of a strong commercial interest may often enable the governing body to provide for the administration of the district without the great expense that would have to be incurred by the home Government if they attempted the direct administration themselves. The history of the development of India under the fostering rule of the Honourable East India Company proves the correctness of this theory, and to her Majesty's ministers it appears that the Royal Niger Company occupies an analogous position in its own district. The charter which was granted to the Niger Company some years ago is sufficiently careful in safeguarding the interests of others, and the success which has attended its administration of the district in question appears fully to justify an extension of its authority in the direction of the Oil Rivers. Surely the great desideratum is the civilisation and improvement of the long neglected races on the West Coast of Africa, to whom Great Britain owes so vast a debt, and so long as that is accomplished it matters little whether it be effected by a commercial corporation endued with exceptional powers, or be left to be gradually evolved as the result of individual effort—except that in the latter case it will take a much longer time to produce the result aimed at.", 'last_edit_date': '1892-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1892#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.664, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Proposed Charter of the African Association', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'on a trading company for administering the whole of the country through which the Niger flows, and now great efforts were being made by the African Association Limited to obtain by Royal Charter similar powers over the palm oil river district—namely, Benin, Toreados, Brass, New Calabar, Bonny, Opobo, and Old Calabar. Since the charter was granted to the Niger Company several of his customers who had been connected with the Niger trade had written to him to say that it was impossible for anyone but the Niger Company themselves to do business, and so they were obliged to give up trading on that river. Consequently he took it upon himself to write to the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, drawing attention to this fact and begging his lordship to take the matter in hand, and see that common fairness was done to all who were anxious to trade in the Niger River. In his own opinion justice would never be done to the natives and the merchants until the administrative department was altogether separated from the trade and from those engaged in trade. He would be very sorry to see such powers as had been given to the Niger Company conferred upon the African Association, because it was quite obvious the interests of the native traders and producers were not likely to be fairly dealt with where all questions in dispute had to be settled by the officers of a trading corporation interested in making the utmost profit for their employers. There was a large body of native traders and producers in the oil district, increasing in number and importance every year. If a monopoly were created, such as was being sought for, the native traders and producers would have only one large customer, who would buy their produce on his own terms. The revenue to be derived from the district, if administered by the government of a Crown colony or annexed to the colony of Lagos, would pay its administrative expenses, the trade of the palm oil rivers district being the most valuable of the West Coast of Africa. The Lagos colony itself, with a trade about a third the volume of that of the oil rivers, showed in ten years a surplus revenue of £65,000. In the memorial the inhabitants of Lagos said: "The rivers comprising the deltas of the Bights of Benin and Biafra form a belt of outlets to a vast produce-yielding interior, rich with natural resources and teeming with hundreds of thousands of Africans who are ready and willing on favourable terms to grant admission to their countries, and to barter their produce and manufacturers for European goods and merchandise. To develop and build up this great commerce, and to Christianise and civilise the native population is the problem which her Majesty\'s Government is now called upon to solve. We have no hesitation in asserting that it can only be done by free, legitimate, and unfettered commerce, fostered and protected directly by her Majesty\'s Government, for there can be no two opinions as to the necessity for free and unfettered competition in the development of the commercial resources of a new and dormant country, and the results to commerce and civilisation in the littoral possessions of her Majesty on this coast abundantly testify as to what may be obtained under proper conditions; and Lagos could be cited as an instance in which the above influences have, within a very few years, transformed it from a barbarous and unimportant place into a progressive civilised colony, with a total export and import trade of £906,811, and a revenue of £58,000 per annum. We unhesitatingly assert that it is impossible for these results to be achieved by a trading company invested with administrative powers; for it would naturally, in its own interest, pursue a policy advantageous to itself, and which could have no other tendency than to stagnate the thrift and industry necessary to the healthy development of a country and its resources." The administrative department of the colony of Lagos had worked very well for all concerned, and it seemed convenient to annex the oil rivers first to that colony. The district extended from 300 to 400 miles on the coast of Africa, between the German boundary and the Cameroons, and the eastern boundary of the British Crown colony of Lagos, and inland to the territories of the Niger Company, and over this area the African Association wished to have the monopoly of trade. The country was densely populated. This district was at present under Imperial protection and the jurisdiction of consular courts, which was better than under the administration of a company formed for private gain. It would be infinitely better under administration as a Crown colony, and he trusted that a Crown colony would be established in connexion with apart from the colony of Lagos.', 'last_edit_date': '1890-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1890#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.671, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Niger Trouble', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A leading article in the same paper goes on to remark that the letter of "African Merchant" expresses the sentiments of the African trade generally outside the Royal Niger Company; but we imagine the writer has misconstrued the Foreign Office statement about a return to the old system being "impracticable, even if it were desirable." "African Merchant" himself must recognize that such retrogression is not practicable, for it would involve leaving the Niger region to the land-grabbing operations of foreigners with a colonization craze. The British Government wished to prevent a foreign protectorate, and they were glad to find persons prepared to save them trouble and expense. They jumped at the offer of the National African Company, and were not too particular about the effect of entrusting the taxing and administrative powers to a party of traders who might be tempted to handicap competitors to secure to themselves a practical monopoly. It is true that the Charter purports to preserve the rights of other traders, but due and licence charges are doing the monopolists\' work on the Niger. What Liverpool merchants ask is that the Charter shall be revoked, and the administrative powers conferred on a non-trading organization. In the present company the dual position of governors and traders is anomalous, and leaves the management open to suspicion. The quotation from the Foreign Office letter suggests that Lord Salisbury has misconceived the desires of independent merchants and traders. They do not wish to return to the old system, but to secure such arrangements as will prevent the trade of the Niger being injured for the benefit of a chartered and limited company. They have established a case for that inquiry which should have preceded the grant of a charter. The incubus is the more galling from the circumstance that authority is conferred on a new company, to the detriment of merchants engaged in the trade of the rivers forming the Niger delta. Before the Government adopted so important a step as chartering one set of traders, they should have obtained the views of merchants who know something of the region in question. So far, the agents of the company do not appear to have achieved any administrative triumphs; their capacity seems to be limited to providing fellow-traders with grievances and driving out of the river the smaller class of traders. Such, at least, is the view of Liverpool merchants in the African trade, and their story should be investigated, and not officially pooh-poohed.', 'last_edit_date': '1887-05-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_05_1887#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.663, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Such, in brief, are the powers with which Major MacDonald is intrusted for the administration of the region to which he has been appointed. The “Africa Order in Council” referred to, deals with all contingencies likely to arise, in minute detail. In a region like that of the Oil Rivers, one cannot expect law and order to be enforced in the same rigid manner as in Europe, or even in the Cape, or an old Crown colony. Much must be left to the Commissioner’s tact and discretion. A body of Haussas are now being enlisted for the police service, and in time we may hope that the law will reach well into the interior, and that free traffic will be carried on without the intervention of middlemen. The numerous creeks and rivers form useful waterways, though they are hotbeds of malaria. It will be the business of the Commissioner and his staff, moreover, to encourage and even carry on experiments in the way of introducing new cultures and new industries. Major MacDonald has been in communication with Kew and with Sir Alfred Moloney, who has done such good work in Lagos. He will take out with him a large supply of seeds of various kinds, and begin by establishing an experimental garden at Old Calabar.\n\nMajor MacDonald’s own head-quarters will be at Old Calabar, where there is some kind of Consular building. But, of course, he will be pretty constantly on the move. His Vice-Consuls will be stationed as follows: General Hammill on the Bonny River; Mr. T. A. Wall at Old Calabar; Captain H. L. Gallwey on the Benin River; Captain F. Synge on the Forcados; Captain MacDonald on the Brass River; Mr. W. Armstrong on the Opobo River. Each of them will, of course, exercise jurisdiction on his own river, but Major MacDonald will be in constant communication with them, and it is hoped that very soon all the rivers will be connected by telegraph. The treasurer of the Commissionership is Mr. J. F. Roberts, while Mr. Tanner is Major MacDonald’s private secretary. There are besides four Consular clerks—Mr. Steains, Mr. C. Harrison, Mr. F. Wilding, and Mr. G. Quilter. This is a large staff, but not too large for the many duties which will have to be performed, in a climate where it is hardly safe to stay for more than a year at a time. It is hoped that the Customs dues to be collected will defray the cost of administration. Of course, the whole arrangement is a compromise. But it is to be expected that in time, under Major Macdonald, the progress made will be such as to justify the taking over of the Oil Rivers as a Crown colony. British connexion with West Africa has had many vicissitudes. Our colonies have been abandoned; have been made over to companies; taken over by the Crown, and generally treated without any sort of continuity of policy. Now that we have put our hands to one of the richest commercial regions on the continent, it is to be hoped we shall persevere in a policy of gradual development.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-08-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_08_1891#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.665, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Royal Niger Company', 'section_title': '', 'content': "There are, however, two main alternatives between which the Government—and ultimately, perhaps, the taxpayer—may be called upon to decide. It is a matter of fairly unanimous consent, to which Lord Selborne's published letter has given official sanction, that the time has come to separate the functions of commerce and administration in the Niger territories. No one, perhaps, is a more cordial advocate of this view than the Governor of the Niger Company. There is no disagreement between the authorities principally concerned and the public upon the fundamental aspect of the question, but the difficulty which may arise will be in connexion with the execution of any practical proposal. Hitherto the achievements of the Niger Company and the administration of its territories have cost the taxpayer nothing. It was necessary that the money to meet these expenses should be provided from private sources, and the trade of the Company was the method by which it was provided. To keep the administration on its feet it was absolutely essential that the Company as a trader should be successful. Hence care and capital have been devoted to its commercial organisation, and as it could not without suicide in the present conditions of a young trade encourage competitors on easy terms it has acquired the reputation of a monopolist. As a matter of fact, the administrative regulations of the Company are under the strictest Imperial supervision, and they do not discriminate in a single particular against other trade. Legally all trade in the Company's territories is on an footing equal with its own. As a trader it pays exactly the same Customs dues and conforms to the same obligations as other traders, but actually its position gives it advantages, especially in the matter of transport, with which no firm organised on a less extensive scale could profitably compete. This position the Company is willing to renounce, but it is clear that in such an event the money which has hitherto been provided by these means to meet the cost of administration and development must be derived from other sources, and the shareholders of the Company must be enabled to withdraw their invested capital upon reasonable terms. It is with the shareholders' money that the whole Nigerian enterprise has been carried out. If the time has now come for the Imperial Government to take over Nigeria the taxpayer who supports the Government must be prepared to bear the cost.", 'last_edit_date': '1897-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1897#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.66, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Great Evils and Injustice Requiring Prompt Remedy', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The governor-generalship of the West Coast of Africa is a complete failure; experience shows that it does not work well, while it entails a great expense on Sierra Leone, and the only compensation she gets in return is to be called Head-quarters. The Governor-in-Chief of the West Coast, whose principal time ought to be occupied in dealing with matters of Sierra Leone, with which he is directly connected (owing to the additional employment given him, to superintend the affairs of the minor settlements), can scarcely find time to attend to matters connected with his own immediate government with any degree of satisfaction; for when he should be at his seat regulating and adjusting the public machinery of Sierra Leone, he is away to some other place, settling some petty disputes between some petty chiefs—disputes with which he is as incapable of dealing as the Lord Mayor of London. What does the Governor-in-Chief, who resides at Sierra Leone, know of the manners, customs, and habits of the Fantees and Ashantees to qualify him for dealing with matters connected with those tribes? He governs over a people dissimilar in every respect, and is governed only by hearsay information, which is very often at variance with facts. The local administrators who dwell among these tribes, and who have thereby the opportunity of becoming personally acquainted with the laws and customs of these people under their immediate control, ought, if proper care be exercised by the Colonial office in its appointments, to be more competent to adjust matters between them than any governor-in-chief of Sierra Leone, who has come among them on a flying visit, and with no other knowledge than such as he calls on the way. You would perhaps laugh right out if you were told that the King of the Bulloms was authorised to regulate the government of Sierra Leone; but surely this is not more ridiculous than giving the Governor-in-Chief power to meddle in the matters of all the various tribes on the West Coast. The new system, then, is of no practical utility, but rather a great disadvantage to Sierra Leone. There was some hope in the beginning that it would be the means of great improvements, but it has been fairly tried and has failed, sadly failed; and what is left now is that it is necessary to do away with it, and confine every governor to the immediate government of his own colony, and not to allow him to interfere with the affairs of other settlements, which he cannot possibly understand or manage. The present system is a great injustice to Sierra Leone, and it is high time that it should be remedied.', 'last_edit_date': '1870-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1870#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.661, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'GAMBIA—ITS ADMINISTRATION AND THREATENED CESSION.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—That the settlements in the River Gambia are suffering from being under the management of the Governor of Sierra Leone, or, as he is, in the technical language of Bumbledom, called "Governor of the West African Settlements," is a fact patent to every practical man on the West Coast. That the other West African Colonies, such as Lagos and the Gold Coast, are also suffering from the same cause is equally clear, and that the great and important colony of Sierra Leone feels her interests to be sadly compromised by the so-called consolidation of all the settlements into a general government, with local administrators at the Gambia, Cape Coast, and Lagos, is clearly shown by the able Editor of the West African Liberator (published at Sierra Leone) in several of his leaders, but more especially in one dated 5th September of last year, from which I extract the following paragraph. Speaking of the consolidation he says: "But this having been put into practice has turned out a complete and disastrous failure, and, instead of proving a benefit to, has only brought suffering on them all (i.e., in all the settlements on the West Coast), in consequence of the evils which spring from having two masters to rule in each, minus Sierra Leone, and she, sad to say, has turned out, as usual, to be the greatest of the sufferers." After illustrating in his usual clear and forcibly style the manner in which Sierra Leone suffers from this great official mistake, he goes on to say: "This interference with the other settlements is the cause of much mischief. By it the various administrators have lost their patronage, and with it their influence. It is out of their power to reward men of merit in their own governments, but they must submit to any appointments made by Sierra Leone, which has aroused great dissatisfaction, as complaints from the Gambia show. The governor-in-chief has as much as he can attend to at his own station if he were ever so industrious, and to divide his time is to make him perform his work imperfectly and unsatisfactorily. The evil can only be got rid of by placing the settlements as they were before, by confining each governor to his immediate governments, thereby preventing the one from meddling with the business of the other. Under such an arrangement individual responsibility would be felt, but under the present system no one holds himself responsible, so that should any difficulty arise we may rest assured that each will try to throw the burden on the shoulders of the others. Then, again, a fearful expense is entailed, for, among other things, a steamer must be supported to keep up a ruinous system. So much for having two rulers. It is true there are governors-in-chiefs in the West Indies as well as in the West Coast, but it must be borne in mind that these West India Islands have their own representative institutions to protect their internal affairs. They have self-government, and all the governor-in-chief has to do is to supervise. But on the West Coast he is the legislature itself, the constructor and supervisor of all measures; in a word, he is absolute and rules over the people, who are powerless, just as he pleases, and disposes of their interests as he sees proper."', 'last_edit_date': '1870-12-12', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1871#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.665, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We reproduce elsewhere two important papers relating to West Africa. One is a survey of the Oil Rivers Protectorate, furnished by an evidently well-informed correspondent of the London *Times*, on the occasion of Major McDonald and his staff sailing to inaugurate the new administration over 350 miles of seaboard and a large but undefined region inland. The other document is the Report of the Annual Meeting of the Royal Niger Company, describing the progress of settlement in their Niger territories. It is estimated that no less than half-a-million square miles are covered by their treaties or reserved to their influence by international arrangements. Both of these documents are interesting reading, as they speak hopefully and with justifiable confidence of development and progress. It may not be amiss to point out that, owing to the relative positions of these two British possessions, and the long frontier line which they have in common, the future of both largely depends on their administrators working together harmoniously for the common good. There is every reason to believe that this harmony will be maintained. Major McDonald has given many solid proofs of his capacity and tact; while the Niger Company have not only shown great administrative ability, but have successfully lived down the violent and, as it proves, unjustified attacks which were at one time made upon their policy and conduct. Major McDonald has a fine field open to him in the Oil Rivers Protectorate, which possesses a valuable and long-established trade, and can, therefore, with moderate taxation, yield a sufficient revenue for administration and development. We venture to hope that he will follow the example of the Niger Company in one particular—by largely using coloured agents in dealing with the native tribes. It is well known that some of the most useful work of the Company has been done by their numerous coloured officials. These have, when opportunity offered, ...\n\nproved the capacity of their race, and amply justified the statemanlike policy of the Company in setting aside the absurd prejudices which have elsewhere hampered progress and civilisation. In former times we had the unscrupulous scoundrels and pirates who carried on the slave trade between West Africa and America. To them succeeded the scarcely more polished "palm oil ruffians"—the masters and crews of the sailing vessels which would anchor for about a year in some one of the Oil Rivers, fill up their ships with native produce, and then sail away again. Yearly the improvement continues; more and more the great trading companies of Liverpool and Bristol have realised that their interests are better served by men of good manners and refinement.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-02-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_02_1889#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.669, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE WEST AFRICAN DELIMITATION QUESTION', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Mr. Coke (the chairman), reminded Mr. Hughes that the constitution of this country was not the same as that of foreign countries, and the way other nations managed their affairs was different from the manner adopted by England. hh: Colonial administrations in Africa faced widespread criticism and resistance from both local populations and international observers due to their often oppressive and unpopular practices.
result: The observations from both the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles provide substantial evidence supporting the claim that colonial administrations in Africa faced widespread criticism and resistance due to their oppressive and unpopular practices. The textbook highlights various forms of resistance, including armed uprisings, passive resistance, and cultural expressions of dissent, such as songs and carvings. It details the harsh conditions imposed by colonial rule, such as forced labor, poor working conditions, and lack of educational opportunities, which fueled discontent among African peasants and workers. Newspapers and associations played a crucial role in voicing opposition to colonial injustices, and international observers and historians have criticized colonialism's impact on African sovereignty and culture. Similarly, The African Times articles report instances of misgovernment, such as the appointment of officials without competitive examinations, the combination of incompatible offices, and the imposition of European officials over Africans without due process. They document brutal treatment of natives, including floggings, torture, and murder, as well as the exploitation of African workers in the Congo Free State. The articles also criticize the negative impact of alcohol imports, the renewal of the slave trade, and the colonial administration's focus on policing rather than education, alongside the neglect of sanitary conditions in African towns. While the articles note some efforts by colonial officials to improve conditions, such as appointing Africans to public offices and opening trade routes, the overall narrative aligns with the claim of resistance and criticism from both local populations and international observers, illustrating a complex and multifaceted colonial experience.

tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that support the claim that colonial administrations in Africa faced widespread criticism and resistance due to oppressive and unpopular practices. The articles highlight various instances of misgovernment, such as the appointment of officials without competitive examinations, the combination of incompatible offices, and the imposition of European officials over Africans without due process. There are reports of brutal treatment of natives, including floggings, torture, and even murder, as well as the exploitation and mistreatment of African workers in the Congo Free State. The articles also mention the negative impact of alcohol imports on African societies and the renewal of the slave trade under colonial rule. Additionally, there is criticism of the colonial administration's focus on policing rather than education and the neglect of sanitary conditions in African towns. These observations align with the claim of resistance and criticism from both local populations and international observers, as evidenced by the letters and reports published in the African Times. However, the articles also note some efforts by colonial officials to improve conditions, such as the appointment of Africans to public offices and attempts to open trade routes, indicating a complex and multifaceted colonial experience.

Thus the French were initially unable to deal with the revolt of 1916 in Dahomeyan Borgu because neighbouring groups - the Somba of Atacora, the Pila Pila of Semere and the Ohori among others - were also in revolt. Many European critics of colonialism, sympathetic to African protest, nevertheless also accepted that Africans had little in their 'traditional' patterns of thought which helped them to come to an effective or practical response to attacks on their way of life. The ideologies of revolt were thought of as 'the magic of despair', bound to fail and incapable of pointing to the future. In such a view the resistances, however heroic, were tragic dead ends. 6
Over the last decade or so historians of resistance have sought to combat this sort of interpretation. They have done this in two ways, by asserting strictly secular ideologies of revolt, and by 'disinfecting' religious ideologies.
The chief secular ideology which has been proposed is the concept of 'sovereignty'. These revolts were, whatever their cause, put down ruthlessly by the colonial authorities. Asiwaju has termed 'protest migrations' to the neighbouring British territories.$^{45}$ To avoid recruitment teams, inhabitants of whole villages fled to the bush. As with the slave trade in earlier times, there were gainers as well as losers, and both were to be found within the confines of every colonial territory. ls Ronald E. Robinson and John Gallagher have also described opposition or resistance as consisting of 'romantic reactionary struggles against the facts, the passionate protests of societies which were shocked by the new age of change and would not be comforted'.$^{16}$ But these views are highly questionable and the dichotomy between resisters and so-called collabor› ators is not only mechanistic but simply unconvincing. There were certainly losers and gainers in the slave trade, but there were no gainers this time. Both resisters and so-called collaborators lost in the end, and what is interesting is that it is the so-called romantic leaders and diehards who are still remembered, and have become a source of inspiration to the nationalist leaders of today.$^{17}$ I entirely agree with the conclusion of Robert I. Rotberg and Ali A. Mazrui that 'there is no gainsaying that the introduction of western norms and power, and accompanying controls and constraints, was everywhere in Africa questioned by the peoples affected'. 18 However, whatever strategy the Africans adopted, all of them - with the sole exception of the Liberians and Ethiopians - failed, for reasons that will be discussed below, to maintain their sovereignty, and by the beginning of the First World War, the cut-off date for the first section of this volume, Africa had been subjected to colonial rule. Most of the discussion, if not all of it, has been centred on the dichotomy between resisters, who by implication are to be praised as heroes, and so-called collaborators, who also by implication are to be condemned as traitors. This classification came about as a result of the nationalist struggle for independence in Africa, as elsewhere in the world. Those involved in the movement tended to see themselves as heirs to a long tradition of struggle whose roots go back to the beginning of this century, if not earlier. It was assumed that independence was a good thing and to strive for it was natural. Consequently, all those who had resisted European penetration of Africa, in order to preserve its inde› pendence, were heroes to be emulated and given an honourable place in the histories of the countries that had gained their independence through resistance to colonial rule. Put in these terms, this view is an attempt to use the standards of the present, with the aid of hindsight, to interpret the events of the past. Among the resisters, there were also divisions. There were those who took to armed confrontation with the intruders - active resistance. Curtin and others have pointed out, 'The European movement into Africa coincided with the nineteenthand twentieth-century peak of racism and cultural chauvinism in Europe itself.$^{46}$ The Europeans who moved into Africa during this period, especially between 1900 and 1945 - missionaries, traders, administrators, settlers, engineers and miners alike - were generally imbued with this spirit and therefore condemned everything African - African music, art, dance, names, religion, marriage, systems of inheritance, etc. To be admitted into a Church, an African had not only to be baptized but had to change his name and renounce a whole range of traditional practices. Even the wearing of African dress was banned or discouraged in certain areas and those educated people who insisted on wearing African clothes were branded as having 'gone native'. [{'id': 516, 'article_title': 'LAGOS.', 'full_section_title': 'LAGOS.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1865#article-7', 'issue_date': '23_01_1865', 'content': 'Some commissioner (French, of course), taken up to Abomey by the French Consul at Whydah, has, it seems, been making a fool of himself. It is no joke to have lived six years up the Niger, and to have travelled about as he has done.—Yours,'}, {'id': 814, 'article_title': "GOVERNOR D'ARCY AND HARRY FINDEN", 'full_section_title': "GOVERNOR D'ARCY AND HARRY FINDEN", 'last_edit_date': '04-05-1866', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1866#article-1', 'issue_date': '23_05_1866', 'content': "I trust that you will offer your columns to any of the above-named gentlemen to disprove any item if they can of the above statement, for which cause I beg that you will publish my name with this letter.—Yours truly,

28, Bessborough-gardens, Pimlico, S.W.

**NOTE BY THE EDITOR.—Our columns are at all times open to Governor D'Arcy, Dr. Sherwood, or any other persons whose conduct in the discharge of their official duties may have been objected to by our correspondents or ourselves, our only object being that Africans under British rule, in British Colonies and Settlements on the West Coast, should be governed and treated as British subjects are entitled to be governed and treated.**

---"}, {'id': 1970, 'article_title': "Sir Arthur Kennedy's Appointments to Public Offices", 'full_section_title': "Sir Arthur Kennedy's Appointments to Public Offices", 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1871#article-11', 'issue_date': '23_01_1871', 'content': 'It shows an unhealthy state of feeling on the West Coast that no sooner do we find it to be our duty to express our disagreement with some of the official acts and words of Sir Arthur Kennedy as Governor-in-Chief of the West Coast Settlements, than we receive letters, both from friends and adversaries of Sir Arthur, in which it is taken for granted that, for some reason or other not expressed by us, we have placed ourselves in unreasoning opposition to Sir Arthur in all his acts, and deeds, and words, instead of giving him, as we have so long done, our friendly support. So strongly is this feeling expressed that the list of official appointments of Africans, which we insert on another page, is sent to us with the expression of doubt that we shall insert it. This is very unjust to us, and measuring us by a standard that ought not to be applied to us. So far from feeling any disinclination to do so, we are only too happy to insert anything that can place the many good official acts of the actual Administrator-in-Chief prominently beneath the eyes of all men, and we beg to thank our informant for putting us in possession of the means for showing all that has been done in the very important question of the filling the public offices in Africa with Africans. The list shows that a very steady move in this most right and much desired direction has been made by the present head of the Executive. Having said thus much, we must now be allowed to vindicate our own consistency. We have from time to time praised what has been done in the above-mentioned direction. We praised when and where we thought praise was due; and as we do not know within our own heart what a personal animosity is, we shall never fail to do so. But this does not take from us the right to disapprove when, in our anxiety for the advancement of African interests, we see, or fancy we see, just reason for disapproval. It is complained that we inserted a letter reflecting on the head of the Executive at Sierra Leone for appointing an English mercantile clerk there to a Government office without his being subject to competitive examination. It appears, however, that the facts are as stated; and we must say that we do not think they are fully answered by the statement that some Africans have been moved up a step in public offices without being subject to competitive examination. Our own opinion is that continuous competitive examinations for those who are already in the public employ are unjust; that a man once admitted into an office is entitled to be moved up to the superior grades in the same office, subject to his being reduced again should he show a manifest incompetency. As we understand the letter and complaints we inserted, it was not that a European had been admitted to an office instead of an African, but that he had been admitted without a competitive examination being held for establishing that he was more worthy by his attainments than any of the possible African candidates. It is possible that there was not a disposable African who could have...'}, {'id': 2144, 'article_title': 'A CONTRAST.', 'full_section_title': 'A CONTRAST.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1872#article-4', 'issue_date': '23_02_1872', 'content': 'Sir,—I feel it my duty, at the request of my brother, to give the following account of a conversation of Mr. Fitzjames, the more so as my brother, although not present, has been made privy to it by my having repeated the conversation to him, word for word, as I give it below, on the evening of the day I heard it, and whose duty it has been, as a Government officer, to inform your Excellency of the source of the information.

The conversation took place at Dr. Deane's farm, Fourah Bay, in the month of December, 1861. The parties present besides myself were Dr. and Mrs. Deane, M. Alphonse Seignac, and Mr. Magnus Smith. When Mr. Fitzjames came into the room it was getting dark, and he immediately began speaking in very condemnatory language on the subject of the Board of Inquiry between himself and Mr. Marston. On a light being brought in, he produced an official document, a letter from the Colonial Secretary, founded on the report of the above-mentioned Board of Inquiry, which was read aloud. After the reading of the letter, Mr. Fitzjames, for the space of about fifteen minutes, apparently on account of the letter that had just been read, spoke against your Excellency and your Government in the most unmeasured language; so strong, indeed, that it could not be more so, both in words and gesture. The following among others were the exact words of the judge's letter: your Excellency "a blackguard," "one of those dangerous men," "a great scoundrel," "a man of no principle," "a robber," "that he would see you fall yet," and "that you would go to the deepest pit of hell."

It is painful to me to have to express to your Excellency such language as the judge made use of; but, however graphically I might write, I could not hope to describe Mr. Fitzjames's very demonstrative manner against you, and every one whom he suspected of supporting you and your Government.

Mr. Fitzjames told us that it was his intention to read the letter all over the colony, in order to show what an unprincipled man your Excellency was, thereby to crush you, and all who supported you.

If I might be permitted to offer some excuse for the judge in this unfortunate affair—for it is with reluctance, being but a stranger in the colony, that I have compelled myself to state this conversation—the judge appeared to me a gentleman who was wholly unable to control his temper or his actions.—I am, &c.,'}, {'id': 2192, 'article_title': 'DEPARTURE OF MR. SALMON.', 'full_section_title': 'DEPARTURE OF MR. SALMON.', 'last_edit_date': '04-13-1872', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_04_1872#article-3', 'issue_date': '23_04_1872', 'content': 'Sir,—No sooner did Mr. Usher come back than Mr. Salmon decided to skedaddle. He felt so uncomfortable to be no longer in power, after having made himself universally hated and despised, that he applied at once to go on sick leave—that nice handy excuse for getting away. He goes, and no one says "God bless him!" except, it may be, the mulatto woman whom he installed as "mistress" at Government House, to solace him amid his despotic cares, while he was imprisoning, holding to bail, persecuting, and sending to trial men a thousand times better than himself, the spalpeen! Even the Devil himself would have been welcome, so that we could only get rid of Salmon. You may suppose therefore that Mr. Usher was made something of when he came. It is too early to form an idea of what he will do, but you shall know by the next steamer, which will be in England the middle of April. We feel that you will be anxious for news, as you will not be able to decide what to do for the Fanti Confederation until Mr. Usher's word and deeds have shown what is the feeling or intention of the British Government respecting us.—More in my next.'}, {'id': 5457, 'article_title': 'LETTERS TO THE EDITOR', 'full_section_title': 'LETTERS TO THE EDITOR', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1886#article-11', 'issue_date': '01_12_1886', 'content': '[The Editor cannot hold himself responsible for the opinions of his Correspondents.]*

**COMBINATION OF OFFICES.**

*TO THE EDITOR OF "THE AFRICAN TIMES."*

Sir,—With surprise, I have read in the *Lagos Observer* of Oct. 2, forwarded to me by one of my clients, that Dr. Mattei, Assistant Colonial Surgeon, has been appointed District Commissioner of Lagos, in succession to T. Worall, Esq., who proceeds to England on the usual six months' leave of absence. Can any of your readers on the West Coast of Africa enlighten me as to how the Colonial Surgeon, whose services are necessarily required at the Hospital from time to time, can discharge both duties of Colonial Surgeon and that of District Commissioner efficiently, and to the satisfaction of the public? The inhabitants of Bathurst, Gambia, memorialized H.M. Principal Secretary of State for the Colonies a few months ago on the same irregularity, as I read in your journal of November. I have not the slightest doubt that H.M. Principal Secretary of State for the Colonies will direct that medical officers in charge of hospitals should not be appointed to any other office, unless in connexion with the Medical Department. How on the coast that medical and judicial are one, I cannot tell. I have written to Lagos for full particulars. You shall hear from me again.  
—Yours,  
Patriot.  
Manchester, Nov. 20, 1886.

The paper itself was followed by a most interesting discussion, which was fully reported in the _Colonies and India_, and of which the following are some of the chief points:—'}, {'id': 6109, 'article_title': 'Sir Alfred Moloney on West Africa', 'full_section_title': 'Sir Alfred Moloney on West Africa', 'last_edit_date': '05-20-1891', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1891#article-6', 'issue_date': '01_06_1891', 'content': "In view of my sincere sympathy with the native races, it would seem unintelligible, and indeed ungracious, on my part not to respond to the invitation I have received from the Aborigines' Protection Society, and to the call from the chair. I have been now associated with Western Africa for some years, during which I have been responsible, at different times, for the administration of the Governments of the Gambia, Gold Coast, and Lagos colonies. Such connexion may justify me in appearing here this evening, and in offering a few general remarks, by way of preface to supporting the second resolution on the programme of the current proceedings. Such remarks have necessarily—it will be, I am confident, readily understood—to be of a general character, in view of my official position and of the Report which has just been read. It would be, indeed, ungenerous on my part, nor would it fall within my rights nor within a proper sense of propriety, to support by my presence, or to allow to go unnoticed, any such condemnation as has been passed on a policy which, however high-handed it may at first appear, has unfortunately at times to be resorted to by Governors in Western Africa in the interest of the many. If I have so to speak in explanation of my not feeling at liberty to second the first resolution in its entirety, as had been, I believe, intended, and in no way in justification of any act of my own, I must, at the same time, say I am heartily in accord with the object and aim of this body, as regards its noble and untiring efforts for the protection of Africans, either against themselves or against others.

I can, perhaps, console myself, too, that I have not yet, so far as I know, got within reach of the lash of the criticism of this Society. Such immunity may be due to my good fortune rather than to my management. There may, however, be a good time in store for me."}]
