Inducements for the best men to serve in Africa, but they contribute from their national exchequers towards the creation and initial development of their possessions, sums large in comparison with our petty revenues drawn entirely from local taxation. A striking example is that of the Congo Free State, which, in addition to the magnificent endowment of King Leopold, is subsidised to the extent of £80,000 a year by the Belgian Government. Great Britain, on the other hand, has never contributed a shilling to aid us in our work of exploration, civilisation and extirpation of the slave trade. It would be idle to complain, even if we were disposed to do so, of being thus left entirely to our own resources, and it may be that in the long run we shall profit more from the energy evoked and the liberty fostered by independence of State subsidies and State interference. But it is an indisputable fact that commerce on the Niger has suffered heavily during the last three years from the pecuniary encouragement given to our foreign neighbours. No appreciable effect is indeed produced in respect of those articles of African produce such as gum, kernels, oil and rubber, which are not suited for land carriage over long distances; but in respect of one valuable product—viz., ivory, which is carried on the backs of slaves for immense distances at a small cost, these subsidies, which practically amount to bonuses to the local merchants, have unquestionably diverted a considerable value from the Niger markets to those of more favoured regions, and have thus diminished your annual dividends to the extent of at least 4 per cent. It is not easy to see how this result has benefited the taxpayers of the European States which pay these bonuses out of their home exchequers; but it has undoubtedly enriched the merchants of various nationalities trading in their African possessions at the expense of commerce in unsubsidised British possessions where the whole cost of administration and development has to be met by taxation on trade. Passing from these considerations of our external relations to our neighbours, I will say a few words on our own internal condition, that is on the progress of settlement within our present sphere of operations. You may perhaps remember that at our meeting two years ago I dwelt at considerable length on the great difficulties with which we have had to contend, apart from those arising from the unhealthiness of the climate and from the intermittent residence and consequent want of continuity in our staff in Africa. I pointed out that "we have to deal with 800 tribes who have been for countless generations plunged in idle barbarism, whose sole idea of wealth has been the holding of slaves, and whose main occupation in life has been to acquire such slaves by intertribal war or kidnapping." I am glad to be able to tell you that year by year there has been a steady growth of the whole, some influence and power of the Company—a growth necessarily slow and incomplete, but more rapid than we had ventured to anticipate. The missionaries in the Lower Niger have borne witness to the remarkable progress of peace and security under our rule. You must not understand me as saying that there is not still in those regions a vast amount of gross barbarism and uncurbed ferocity; but only that these have been mitigated and even in some places abated to a degree which more than justifies our presence there as the ruling power. Having achieved such striking success as far up the Niger as Lokoja, we have thought the time ripe for taking similar measures in the Pagan countries to the south of the Lower Benue; where, during the few years since we first established our stations, and probably for many years previously, incalculable miseries have been inflicted on the natives by slave hunters from the North and East. It is an inevitable consequence of these raids that their operations expand year by year in a wider circle, as belt after belt of country is devastated and depopulated, leaving no further prey for the slave hunters; so that tribes whom we had already commenced to train to peaceful commerce and whom we were teaching to utilise the natural resources of that fertile region, have disappeared, most of their members having been either killed or captured as slaves, while the more fortunate are hiding amongst the forests and rocks in hopes of escaping the fate of their companions. The region of which I am speaking is at present one of the principal hunting grounds for supplying the enormous and apparently insatiable demand for slaves in the Central Soudan and even as far as Morocco. You will at once understand that if we longer delayed taking the necessary remedial measures all hope of developing those fertile and once populous regions must be abandoned. We are therefore impelled by interest, as well as the ordinary feelings of humanity, to act decisively at this, the earliest practicable moment, and to afford these pagan populations— with whom we have made treaties—efficient protection to life, freedom, and property. We have, therefore, ordered the military occupation of this region, which is now being executed. This measure has demanded an increase to our small army and consequently additional expenditure, which must temporarily be met by increased taxation. I must remind you that although the establishment of peace and security will certainly bear fruit in largely increased commerce yielding a larger revenue, the immediate result will be only to preserve the trade already existing. The development which will naturally arise from a sense of security amongst the natives cannot be expected at once. You must remember that the greater portion of the taxation at present falls upon the Company, which is still by far the largest European trader in the territories, although no longer alone there, as at the time of the issue of the Charter. This has confirmed us in the belief that it will be wiser for us not to declare for 1890 more than our usual 6 per cent. dividend. I now move that the Report and Accounts be received and adopted. This was carried, and'}, {'id': 6195, 'article_title': 'THE WEST AFRICAN CRISIS—CONFERENCE IN LONDON', 'full_section_title': 'THE WEST AFRICAN CRISIS—CONFERENCE IN LONDON', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1892#article-2', 'issue_date': '01_04_1892', 'content': '**Mr. Howorth** asked if the Colonial Office would admit that the kings or chiefs were committed to the treaties by the representatives, or was there any dispute about that?

The **Chairman** said that they did not set about the repudiation of treaties as they did in a civilised country, but they simply stopped the roads, as an indication that they did not intend to carry out the treaty. The Colonial Office certainly considered the treaties to be valid.

**Mr. Kenrick, M.P.**, said, with regard to the right of an African potentate to demand dues on produce passing through his country, that might be a wrong method of proceeding, but we knew it was one that was always exercised, and they looked upon it as a very valuable power.

**Mr. King (Bristol)** said that the African merchants disliked the spirit trade, and would be glad to put it down, but if the Government allowed other nations to come alongside of us and compete with us in the spirit traffic, it compelled British merchants to sell spirits to the Natives. They very much preferred exporting English goods and Manchester goods to Hamburg bad spirit, for if the Government would not assist them by annexing territory on the coast of Africa, or making conventions with foreign nations to prohibit the exportation of spirits, how could they expect the British merchants to desist from it. They wished the House of Commons would impress upon the Government to annex every portion of the coast, and where they could conclude treaties with the French and Germans to prevent the importing of those spirits.

**Mr. J. A. Bright, M.P.**, thought that there must be some reason for the King repudiating the agreement which had been made with the native tribe. They ought to have a clear idea how the treaty was obtained, and how it was that so large a revenue was bartered away for the sake of £500 a year. He objected to the exercise of force to make the people take our goods, and thought a great deal could be done by way of conciliation.

**Mr. Giles, M.P.**, said he regarded the sending of our letter back unopened as practically a declaration of war. We should not submit to it from any civilised nation, and why should we do it in the case of an uncivilised tribe? He thought it would be necessary for us to use force to secure the reopening of the route.'}, {'id': 6282, 'article_title': "Monteil's Journey to Lake Tchad", 'full_section_title': "Monteil's Journey to Lake Tchad", 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1893#article-3', 'issue_date': '02_01_1893', 'content': "More than two years since Commandant Monteil left Senegal, immediately after the signing of the Anglo-French Agreement of August 1890, by which the Say-Barrawa line was agreed on as defining the spheres of influence of Great Britain and France in the Central Soudan. About the same time other expeditions, with Lake Tchad as their goal, were sent out by the French Government. Lieut. Mizon was in command of one expedition designed to reach the lake by way of the Benue; another expedition was under the leadership of the unfortunate M. Paul Crampel. Lieut. Mizon found it impossible to reach Lake Tchad, and made for the Sangha river, where he effected a junction with M. de Brazza, and claims by treaties made en route to have cut off the German colony of the Cameroons from expansion towards the interior. Of the various expeditions that of Commandant Monteil has alone been successful.

Commandant Monteil, accompanied by only one European companion, left St. Louis on Oct. 9, 1890, and on Dec. 20, reached Segou, on the Upper Niger. From Segou he struck out for Say, across the great bend of the Niger. On April 21, Wagadugu was reached. At Uro Guelajo, a town of 3,000 inhabitants, Ibrahima, a powerful chief, whose father had befriended Barth, gave the mission a fair welcome, though his counsellors were not friendly to the white men. As Ibrahima is suzerain of a large number of petty chiefs, the treaty made with him is, in Commandant Monteil's view, of especial importance; owing to the good-will of this chief, the mission on its arrival at Say on Aug. 19, met with a cordial reception and no difficulty was found in obtaining a treaty of friendship with France."}]

[{'document_title': 'Leaders', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The possible influence of Germany upon the future development of the "Dark Continent" cannot well be overestimated. On the east, the south, and the west, we see her ever watchful and ready to found a colony, or even a trading station only, and to enter into treaties with the native kings and chiefs; the outcome of all which is sure to be, sooner or later, the subordination of the native to the European influence. In the course of one week recently, there were laid before the Reichstag no less than three treaties under which chiefs of various tribes on the West Coast place themselves and their people under the protection of the German Empire. The meaning of these treaties is, says Kühlow's Trade Review (to which we are indebted for much information as to the German movement all over Africa), sooner or later "annexation," as by them the influence of all other foreign Powers is expressly excluded, while the chiefs place themselves—so far, at least, as all exterior matters are concerned—entirely in the hands of Germany. Under these treaties the natives concerned are assured of protection from foreign foes; but, on the other hand, they undertake not to entertain any warlike intention independently of the Great Power. It is not reasonable to suppose that the natives fully understand the importance of the agreements into which they appear so readily to have entered; but this much at least is clear, that Germany, as she agrees to be responsible for the security of these people in time of trouble, must be prepared to restrain them from anything that would tend to the provocation of surrounding tribes, or from any overt act that would lead to hostilities. We may rest assured that Germany will take good care that the power she has thus obtained will be exercised whenever it suits her policy and the principles of German extension, which have been before her eyes ever since the first conception of a German colonial policy.', 'last_edit_date': '1886-05-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1886#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.645, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Report of the Commissioner appointed to Inquire into the Condition of the British Settlements on the West Coast of Africa.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We have numerous treaties with the natives, beginning from 1826; they relate, in some instances, to cessions of territory, and always contain engagements for the protection of trade, the abolition of slavery, and the preservation of peace. They are not entered into by the natives without great consideration, and as they are rarely, if ever, broken, they are decidedly beneficial to the colony. Moreover, they afford us the plea for proffering our intervention when they show a disposition to quarrel amongst themselves, and in some recent instances our interference has been attended with very good results. The practice which has been long and successfully followed at Sierra Leone, of paying the chiefs small stipends to encourage them in observing these engagements, might advantageously be introduced at the Gambia.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-03-09', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_04_1865#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.654, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Berlin Conference is the all-absorbing topic of the month. The thoughts of those who are interested in the welfare, present and future, of Africa—and that is tantamount to saying the whole civilized world—have been directed to that hall in the Palace of the German Chancellor in which the delegates of the European Powers have met to discuss the question, "What shall we do with it?" The Treaty of Berlin was in the mouth of every one six years ago: then, in this same hall, and under the presidency of "the man of blood and iron" who is the moving spirit at the present gathering, the delegates of Europe met to discuss the best means to be used to bolster up the effete government of Turkey—and ended by taking so much territory away, on the understanding that having less to govern, greater attention could be given to what was still left to the Sublime Porte. But it was well understood that the catastrophe was only deferred; that the final overthrow of the Turkish rule in Europe is inevitable. The present gathering is in every way different to that which preceded it—the object they have in view is to shape the destiny of a continent. We read that on the wall before the Plenipotentiaries hung an immense map of Africa, as if to remind them that their business was not to do with any particular nation, but with a quarter of the world—not with a kingdom that had been great in past days, and, through misgovernment and oppression, had sunk to the level of a tenth-rate Power, but with whole nations concerning whom the page of history is a blank. The future of Africa is in the hands of Europe, and to the Berlin Conference is committed the solution of the question—who is to hold Africa, and on what principles should it be held. The Conference may be said to have arisen in the first instance out of the Congo Treaty of Feb., 1884, between Portugal and Great Britain, which was, in no small measure, due to the discoveries commenced by Commander Cameron and completed by Mr. Stanley, of the immense importance as a trade route of the River Congo, flowing as it does through the heart of Africa, and issuing into the Atlantic Ocean. So long as the trading was confined to a few miles from its mouth, matters were allowed to take their chance. Portugal claimed the sovereignty of the adjacent region, but did nothing to enforce or justify her claim, which was regarded with indifference by most of the Powers, and always disallowed by Great Britain. But when the International African Association came to the front, setting up stations along the river, and thus opening up the interior, when also M. de Brazza claimed a portion of the upper waters for his country, and it was known that France had bargained for what we may call the reversionary interests of the International Association, it became necessary to take some steps to secure order and freedom of trading at the mouths and along the course of what was evidently destined shortly to become one of the leading highways of the world's commerce. Lord Granville saw no better way than by recognizing the sovereign rights of Portugal over the strip of coast at the mouth of the Congo, making this acceptance conditional upon the latter's agreeing to maintain freedom of trade and navigation, and binding her to secure the execution of this promise under the superintendence of an International Commission similar to that which discharges a like office on the lower waters of the Danube. On these terms, and with the addition of the invariable article requiring co-operation in the extinction of the slave trade, a Treaty was drawn up and signed by the Plenipotentiaries on February 26th last. But before the ratification could take place a storm of indignation was aroused on all sides, the merchants of the two nations principally concerned being loudest in their expressions of disapproval, with the result that the Treaty was never ratified, but allowed to drop out of existence. So that there still remained for disposal the question of the Congo—who should possess it, and how far could the principles of free trade and navigation be maintained? To complicate matters still further, came the action of the Germans, who were suddenly possessed with a mania for colonization, and proceeded to annex various districts along the West Coast, as it is alleged, without paying due regard to the previously acquired rights of others. In abandoning the Congo Treaty, Lord Granville had let fall the suggestion that Portugal and Great Britain might unite in proposing to the other Powers some international arrangement which would prove more acceptable. Prince Bismarck took the hint, and thereupon issued invitations to the Powers to send representatives to Berlin to discuss the measures to be taken, and the result is the assembling of this Conference, which must ever exercise a wide influence upon the future of Africa. It would be premature at present to discuss the proceedings of the Conference and the special Committee of Experts, but one thing would seem to be assured—viz., we shall obtain the material and practical results desired, in fuller measure and with surer guarantees than could be looked for under the Anglo-Portuguese Treaty.', 'last_edit_date': '1884-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1884#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.643, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Niger and Territories on the West Coast of Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We have been requested to publish the following correspondence:—

"Chamber of Commerce, Manchester, Nov. 2, 1883.

"My Lord,—In November last year this Chamber addressed to your lordship a memorial praying that the earnest endeavours of Her Majesty's Government might be directed towards promoting a friendly understanding with other European Governments in order that the sovereign and territorial rights of the natives of the Congo River, and of the adjacent territories on the West Coast of Africa, might be respected and maintained, and that there should be no interference on the part of any Power with the existing freedom of navigation and commerce.

"The attention of other European nations is now being devoted to the extension of commerce, and to the increasing importance, not only of the Congo, but also of the Niger and other rivers, which are the principal means of communication and of trade with the populous tribes in the centre of Africa, and there is reason to fear that they are seeking to annex territories, and also to secure such concessions from native rulers as may enable them to put a hindrance to that freedom of trade and navigation which has hitherto been enjoyed on the West Coast of Africa.

"Your lordship has recently been informed of certain proceedings of French officers on the Niger and the Bonny, and other rivers and places on the African coast, which call for the serious consideration of Her Majesty's Government. When it is remembered that the trade in most of these rivers has been mainly established and carried on by British merchants, and that it has been from Great Britain that the ruling chiefs have hitherto sought and obtained assistance, and also that British officers have for many years undertaken the responsibility of maintaining peace and order among them, Her Majesty's Government cannot be surprised that the proceedings of French officers above alluded to have caused considerable apprehension among the merchants.

"Although the influence which Great Britain has exercised in the Bight of Benin has been in a great measure only moral, it has benefited the trade, tended to promote progress among the natives, and increased their respect for the British Government, whilst securing the lives and property of European settlers. The interference of any other European Power with native rights cannot but tend to endanger the peace, and to hinder both civilization and the development of trade, and of friendly relations with these African tribes.', 'last_edit_date': '1883-11-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1883#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.643, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Congo and the Conference in Reference to Commercial Geography', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Here I hold a paper signed by M. Arntz, in which the question given to him was—"Can the independent chiefs of savage tribes cede their States?" This question presents two aspects—first, the rights of the grantor; secondly, the rights of the grantee. First, they say, with regard to the law of nations, we must ask ourselves whether the chiefs of savage tribes can make treaties, &c., or whether the tribes they represent are considered as States capable of making international treaties. The answer given was, that the rules of the law of nations had been looked upon as the special privilege of Christian races; and it was only in 1856 the Porte, by the Treaty of Paris, was permitted to participate in the advantages of international law and of the European concert. Therefore his opinion is that it was obligatory on these nations that they should recognize these laws, and they could not allow those nations to participate in its advantages who did not recognize this law as obligatory upon themselves. Publicists and moralists taught that Christian sovereigns should conduct themselves honestly, and observe the rules and justice of equity and Christian morality. Feeble, half-savage races, deprived as yet of the benefits of civilization, are now no longer considered merely as prey for the rapacity of civilized nations, or as furnishing a field for their enterprise. But what are the conditions under which a State can be capable of negotiating treaties? According to Klüber, a certain number of men and families congregating together, and fixing their abode in a country, associating themselves and submitting to a common chief with the purpose of insuring the safety of all, form a State. Sovereignty is acquired by a State at the time of its formation, or when it frees itself from a condition of dependence. Therefore, only territories without masters, that is, those in which no sovereign power is as yet established, can be rightfully available for occupation.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-05-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1885#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.653, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Progress on the West African Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The rivers are connected by a network of cross creeks, being indeed one delta; so from the Opobo Ja Ja's people found their way to the interior oil markets, and the oil trade of Opobo was established. The trade flourished, and Ja Ja was respected for his fair dealing and his great ability to govern his own people. Meanwhile, treaties of friendship had been made, courts of equity had been established in the various stations; regulations for trade, customs, and other subjects of interest were decided, the British Consul inspecting the proceedings from time to time. Of late years there has been a growing inclination on the part of the traders to establish themselves up the rivers at the interior oil markets, so dispensing with the services of the coast tribes. In Opobo this movement was resisted by Ja Ja, for the reason that the welfare of his people depended upon their employment as middlemen, and as no customs would be paid on the produce bought by the Europeans. He was last year accused of obstructing the Europeans from proceeding to the interior, at the time that his son was in England complaining that the Europeans were invading his markets. Ja Ja was made prisoner by Consul Johnstone, and carried off to Accra. An inquiry was held at Accra upon the charges brought against Ja Ja, and the Admiral holds that they are mainly proved; and Ja Ja is deposed, and will not be allowed to return to the Opobo river. He will, however, be allowed an annual pension of £800 for life.

The principle having been laid down that Europeans may trade in the interior, it becomes imperative to assume definite authority over the district. The "customs" have been abolished, a uniform export duty of 2s. 6d. per ton being levied instead. As things stand, we make no pretence to the sovereignty of the country; we only constitute ourselves the final authority in matters of dispute between the natives and traders of whatever nationality, and debar our continental neighbours from proclaiming themselves masters of the country. Whether things will remain as they now are is the doubtful point; pretexts for occupation are so easily found when wanted that it would be rash to answer. Some tribe is reached who cannot understand dual control; they insist on customs, perhaps; are "chastised" by the Consul; they retaliate, and finally an occupation is proclaimed. This is the danger to which we are exposed, for the destruction of the natives means loss to the traders and the abandonment of commerce. Let this be borne in mind, and we may escape the slough into which other nations have fallen.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1888#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.648, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE "COMING" CONTINENT.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In an article, entitled "Africa for Africans," published in a magazine issued in Washington, U.S.A., the vast possibilities of progress and development possessed by this continent are so eloquently and aptly set forth that we quote the passage *in extenso*:

"Africa is to-day the object of more interest on the part of a larger number of people than any other quarter of the globe. England, France, Portugal, Germany, and Italy are attempting to obtain titles to the country. England has made annexation of the coast lying adjacent to her colony of Sierra Leone; France is forcing her way on the Senegal and toward the head-waters of the Niger; she threatens to annex the coast from the Gaboon to the Congo, some 250 miles, and is running her lines on the Upper Congo. Her Chamber of Deputies has granted the De Brazza mission, by a vote of 449 to 3, a credit of a million and a quarter of francs. The Portuguese Government has appointed explorers and examined the Congo country, and assumes to exercise control over all the territory at the mouth of the Congo. The German Reichstag has increased its annual appropriation for the exploration of Africa. Italy has despatched a party to Abyssinia for geographical and mercantile purposes. She has also concluded treaties which promise to make Assab a centre of commerce. The Sultan of Morocco has authorized Spain to take possession of Santa Cruz del Mar, and the Sultan of Zanzibar has purchased six superior steamers to constitute a regular coast service, in the interest of commerce and for the suppression of the slave-trade. The International African Association, which owes its origin to the philanthropic initiative of Leopold II., King of the Belgians, has received large subscriptions and pushed forward exploring expeditions to start and equip the line of hospitable and scientific stations which are to bound the East and West Coast, and form a civilizing girdle around Central Africa. And the results following the explorations of Livingstone and Stanley and De Brazza are attracting the attention of the civilized world. What was a 'Dark Continent,' by the indomitable energy of these explorers, seems likely to prove the richest quarter of the globe. Not only does the land produce, with slight persuasion of tillage, admirable crops of cotton and coffee, but the soil is rich in diamonds on its southern coast, and in iron on its northern. Captain Burton has asserted that he knows nothing to equal the prodigious wealth of the land, even in California, or in the Brazils. 'Gold dust is panned by native women from the sands of the sea shore. Gold spangles glitter after showers in the streets of Axím. Gold is yielded by the lumps of yellow swish that rivet the wattle walls of hut and hovel.'"', 'last_edit_date': '1884-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1884#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.654, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Progress on the West African Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The African rivers situate in the Bight of Benin, commonly known as the Oil Rivers, have been placed under the protectorate of Great Britain. The protectorate, announced at Bonny, in December last, by Admiral Sir Walter Hunt Grubb, extends from the right bank of Benin river to the Rio del Rey, thus including Brass, New and Old Calabar, Bonny, Opobo, and other important trading stations.

Two series of considerations, the internal and external, have combined to render action imperative, and a retrospective view may not be uninstructive. Since the abolition of the export of slaves, these localities have been the sites of trading stations, palm oil being the chief article of export. The traders have been, with few exceptions, British, and the capitalists mostly Liverpool merchants. The natives allowed trading hulks to be anchored and commerce conducted on payment of fixed sums, known as "comey." Bonny, Brass, and Old Calabar are among the oldest of these trading ports, the native chiefs being also the native traders. They possessed numerous slaves who were sent with merchandise to the interior markets to collect oil, which was brought to the stations and sold to the whites. Among the Bonny chiefs was the father of Ja Ja, late King of Opobo; his son was brought up to the management of the business, and on his father's death he succeeded to his position. Of his enemies the most powerful was Oko Jumbo, who lost no opportunity to humiliate him. The Europeans could only let matters take their course; they regretted constant fighting of Oko Jumbo and Ja Ja, but the relations between the Europeans and natives being strictly commercial, nothing could be done. Suffering reverses, Ja Ja was forced to fly with the remnant of his people after great slaughter at the hands of Oko Jumbo. He collected his scattered family, dependants, and slaves, and made his escape to the Opobo river. There Ja Ja found a place for his town, and established himself as King of Opobo.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1888#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.666, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH WEST AFRICA AND THE TRADE OF THE INTERIOR.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The trading operations of Europeans in West Africa are carried on after the following manner: The trader selects a site suitable—generally by the side of a river or creek, or along the seashore—and comes to terms with the owner of the soil or the native chief of the district for the leasing of the land, the natives retaining a dislike to alienating any part of their country. All these trading establishments are constructed mainly of corrugated iron, with iron framework, though the interior may be lined with timber. The houses are well built, well ventilated, and comfortably furnished, and have all the appearance of a bright, pleasant home. With every trading colony of any size—that is to say, where there are more than three or four trading houses—there is a medical officer, jointly paid by the various firms.

Perhaps in no body of Englishmen abroad has such an improvement taken place as in the class of men who now conduct the trade with the natives in West Africa. In former times we had the unscrupulous scoundrels and pirates who carried on the slave trade between West Africa and America. To them succeeded the scarcely more polished "palm oil ruffians"—the masters and crews of the sailing vessels which would anchor for about a year in some one of the Oil Rivers, fill up their ships with native produce, and then sail away again. The conduct of the masters and seamen of these trading vessels was often outrageous. The way in which those earlier traders treated the natives was simply regulated by the power of the natives to avenge ill-treatment. With the missionaries it can be imagined how these ruffians came in conflict; and so angry were they at the prospect of the missionaries protecting their victims, or interfering with them, that they bribed and frightened the native chiefs, and used every effort to prevent the missionaries obtaining any hold on the country. The increase of steam navigation, and consequent supplanting of these sailing-vessel voyages; the more permanent settlement of European merchants on shore, where they began to build houses; the establishment and growing influence of various forms of administrative Government; and, it may also be said, the spread of civilisation, refinement, and sobriety among the seafaring class generally, brought about a better state of affairs in the trading colonies of West Africa. Yearly the improvement continues; more and more the great trading companies of Liverpool and Bristol have realised that their interests are better served by men of good manners and refinement.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-02-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_02_1889#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.643, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The history of British commercial connexion with this part of Africa may be briefly told. More than 100 years ago the ships of one or two Liverpool and Bristol merchants were actively engaged in exchanging cargo for slaves, ivory, and palm oil. Fifty years ago the four or five leading houses in the trade were already strong enough to dispense with the profits of slave traffic and rely on the ordinary channels of commerce. It was not, however, without great sacrifices and outlay of money on their part that the change was made palatable to the great native chiefs of the Bights of Benin and Biafra, who had grown immensely wealthy and powerful by the trade in humanity. To induce a better business in native products, loans and presents of cotton goods, hardware, and other articles were made on an extensive scale, and the palm oil trade thus rapidly developed in importance. Examination of the shipping books of one of the greatest firms of that period (1843) shows about forty-six various assortments of articles shipped in twelve months; and the changes brought about by improving civilisation and persistent commercial effort are evidenced in the 300 or more distinct and separate items of export now found in the invoice books of Oil Rivers merchants. Comparative statistics are not available in any authentic form. The quantity of palm oil imported into Europe has varied very little all along, though the tendency has been slightly to increase. A new trade, however, rivalling in dimensions that in oil, has sprung up through the activity of English merchants, and palm kernels—formerly waste product—are bought up in great quantities for shipment to European crushing mills. Ivory has all but disappeared. Ebony and other woods are increasing in volume, and cocoa quickly rising into importance, as well as rubber.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-08-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_08_1891#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.647, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'GERMAN ANNEXATIONS IN AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The newly-formed African Trade Section of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce has been considering the question of the recent annexation by Germany of ports in Africa where British trade is largely carried on, and the following letter was signed and forwarded to Earl Granville:

"**Liverpool, October 8, 1884.**', 'last_edit_date': '1884-11-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1884#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.642, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'FRENCH AFRICAN EXPLORATION.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The writer proceeds to give some interesting information about a European established in these parts, one M. Philippe Broyon, a native of Switzerland. "M. Broyon is about thirty-three years of age. He is tall, thin, and muscular, and looks like a soldier. He did not marry the daughter of Mirambo, as has been stated, but a negress whom he rescued from slavery. He was formerly employed at Zanzibar, but subsequently took to travelling in Africa and carrying on the ivory trade. The English often tried to purchase his services, but without success, for he does not like them. However, forced by necessity, he has accepted their offers, and is now conducting a caravan of merchandise for the English.

As regards one of the monarchs of Africa, the Abbé says: "Mirambo enjoys in Europe a reputation far beyond his merits. He is a cruel tyrant, whose caprice is the only law known. His army reckons scarcely more than four hundred men. If he does not make the Europeans pay the right of passage, he knows how to make up for it in another and far more advantageous way. He proposes to every white man who crosses his country the pact of blood. At the end of the ceremony he makes a few gifts, but he besieges the European in return with demands which have to be satisfied."

The writer concludes with some remarks respecting the doings of the English. He says: "The English occupy Mpapona, which is a strategical position of the first order. All the routes which lead to Unyamezi pass by it. It is not six months that they have been there, and already four handsome stone houses have been built. A clergyman, a mason, and a carpenter compose all the personnel of the station. They are eminently practical men. The English have founded another station in the Ukereone, a third in the Uganda, and a fourth at Ujiji. The power of the Arabs in these parts is decreasing daily. The ivory trade no longer satisfies their wants, and as the slave-trade is prohibited, they will soon be forced to leave the colonies which they have founded in the interior of Africa, and the English will take their place.', 'last_edit_date': '1879-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1879#article-26', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.642, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The People of Lagos upon European Influence upon the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"Looking at the question from an economist's point of view, commercial intercourse with foreigners enriches our country. It enables us to import those commodities for the production of which the climate and soil of foreign countries are best calculated, and to export in payment those articles for which our own situation is better adapted. It is virtually a mode of cheapening production, the commodities exported rising in value, and those imported decreasing in value, caused by the increase of demand in the one, and of supply in the other. At the same time, the manufacture of those commodities for which we have no particular facilities is decreased. Take cloth, for instance; the manufacture of cloth out here costs at least a fifth more than if imported. West Africa has great natural advantages for the cultivation of the palm tree; thus the manufacture of palm oil is carried on with great success. This commodity is enough not only to supply the wants of the people, but to satisfy the demands of England, Germany, and other European countries, which, owing to climate, are unsuited for the cultivation of the palm. Thus, from an economist's point of view, commercial enterprise of Europeans in Africa is good for three reasons. First, it enables us to profit by the inventions and discoveries of the Europeans, from whom we get steamers, canals, railways, and the minor advantages of art and science, and also a certain amount of refinement in dress and manners. Then, being dependent on each other for a large amount of comfort and enjoyment, it forms a powerful principle of union, and binds the society of nations together by the common and powerful ties of mutual interest and reciprocal obligation. And, lastly, by bringing us into competition with foreigners, the division of labour is carried to its farthest extent; it stimulates our industry, and forces routine to give way to invention. Commerce is the principal medium for the propagation of Christianity. In some West African countries, Europeans are at first only admitted for commercial purposes. Up the Niger and at Bonny, for instance, persecution of converts to Christianity, especially by slave-holders, was of common occurrence; but this has been greatly modified by the interposition of the European merchants. When making treaties with native tribes, the Consuls usually stipulate for religious toleration. Again, missionaries have to avail themselves of commercial conveniences such as steamers, and also of commercial protection and aid; how would the money for missionary enterprise be forthcoming but for commerce? What is religion but an exalted form of civilization? The Bible contains as good a code for the improvement of mind and manners as any book extant.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-02-16', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1885#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.66, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Future of Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Dr. Karl Peters, on March 5, delivered a lecture on "The Future of Africa," before a meeting of the Foreign Press Association, held at the Society of Arts, Adelphi, London. Dr. Peters said that there were to be found in Africa a number of cool and healthy high plateaux, where the white man could not only live in comfort, but where he found all conditions for agricultural and pastoral pursuits just as in his old country. There were large and mighty rivers, whose alluvial tracts made the cultivation of all kinds of tropical vegetation possible. There were not wanting direct inducements for immigration such as were offered to the white man's imagination by the existence of precious metals and precious stones, and a later generation of colonists would be able to use throughout the entire continent, from north to south, iron for their immediate wants, and in many districts coal required by modern industry. A modern traveller had truly said that "the greatest treasure of Africa consists in the inexhaustible labour force of its inhabitants." The Native population, which was estimated at about 200 millions, only required to be organised by the whites in order to raise the natural wealth of the continent. A sound connexion of justice with proper severity towards the blacks was the correct principle of conduct to act upon. Africa required railways and highways in every part for the purpose of its economic development and civilisation. Rinderpest must be exterminated. The whole African question was the question of communication, and in the solution of this question lay the conditio sine qua non of the future of the Dark Continent. A vote of thanks was passed to Dr. Peters at the conclusion of the lecture.', 'last_edit_date': '1897-03-05', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/05_04_1897#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.648, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE UNITED STATES AND THE CONGO.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'NEW YORK, Jan. 10.

The New York Chamber of Commerce has adopted a resolution requesting President Arthur to appoint a commission to confer with the African International Association, of which the King of the Belgians is the President, for the purpose of securing for other countries free commerce on the Congo river, which is at present monopolised by the Portuguese.', 'last_edit_date': '1884-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1884#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.642, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: Colonial governance in West Africa, exemplified by roles like that of the governor in Cape Coast, involved public duties with no separation from personal actions, required significant diplomatic skill, and was characterized by hierarchical, career-oriented structures and rotating administrators, which allowed some African leaders limited autonomy within the colonial framework.
result: The claim about colonial governance in West Africa, particularly roles like that of the governor in Cape Coast, is supported by observations from both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles. The textbook describes the hierarchical and career-oriented structures of colonial administration, where European administrators wielded significant power, often acting as sovereigns within their territories. It highlights the use of indirect rule, granting African leaders, such as chiefs, limited autonomy as intermediaries between colonial authorities and local populations, though it does not specifically mention the governor in Cape Coast or the explicit need for diplomatic skill. The lack of separation between public duties and personal actions is emphasized, with colonial administrators often becoming surrogate chiefs, blurring official roles and personal influence. The rotation of administrators is implied through the mention of reposting or removing chiefs to meet colonial needs, suggesting a dynamic administrative environment. Complementing this, The African Times articles underscore the public nature of the governor's role, with no clear separation between personal actions and public duties, as evidenced by scrutiny of Governor Pine's actions and criticism of Governor Ussher's conduct. The need for diplomatic skill is highlighted in the governor's responsibilities, such as arbitrating and advising native chiefs and dealing with foreign powers, as noted by Sir Francis Fleming. The articles also detail the career paths of officials like Sir William Alexander George Young, supporting the hierarchical and career-oriented structure, and mention the rotation of administrators, aligning with the claim of rotating administrators. While the articles do not explicitly discuss the autonomy of African leaders, they reference interactions with native chiefs and local leaders like King George Pepple, indicating some involvement in governance. Together, these sources provide a nuanced view that supports many aspects of the claim, while also highlighting the complexities and challenges of colonial governance in West Africa.

[{'document_title': 'Methods and institutions of European domination', 'section_title': 'Colonial rule and structure', 'content': "The best resume of his policy is found in a set of instructions he issued to his officers in 1906, in which he argues for 'a single Government in which the Native Chiefs have well-defined duties and an acknowledged status equally with the British officials'.$^{10}$ The basis of what was to become the system of indirect rule was therefore one of co-operation, not sub› ordination, with the British Resident acting primarily in an advisory, not an executive capacity, and with the African 'chief - in this instance, the Fulani emir - continuing in a traditional role which was now carefully guided, not rigidly fixed by the imposed colonial administration. Association, he therein stated, is 'indirect adminis› tration, with the preservation but improved governance of the institutions of the conquered peoples, and with respect for their past'. '$^{3}$ With the publication in 1923 of Sarraut's La mise en valeur des colonies françaises, the policy was given the aura of official sanctity.
Originally suggested for Indochina and later extended as policy to Africa, 'association' was none the less geographically limited as a colonial practice. Only in Morocco did the French seriously consider it, and there primarily because of the attention given to indigenous affairs by the ResidentGeneral, Louis-Hubert Lyautey, who, in the initial years of the protec› torate, ruled with few restrictions from the metropolitan government. Throughout Morocco the forms of the Sherifian state were preserved, while at the local level administrative activities were strikingly similar to those proposed by Lugard. The French contrôleur civil was to perform in an advisory not a supervisory capacity with respect to the cadi, a Muslim official fulfilling magisterial functions in accordance with the shari'a. A comparable arrangement existed in the Spanish-dominated portion of Morocco where the cadi was guided in his role by the Inventare, the Spanish counterpart of the contrôleur civil. The cadi was also administratively retained as before in Italian Somaliland, but there he was joined in the responsibilities of local government by assigned warrant chiefs.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.69, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The social repercussions of colonial rule: the new social structures', 'section_title': 'Change and continuity', 'content': "Any easy generalization on the response of African societies to the European impact is thus bound to be misleading. One must always bear in mind the territorial vastness of the continent, the rich diversity and variegation of African cultures, differences in individual and group temperaments and psychologies - and thus the fact that response to even similar stimuli was likely to vary not only from individual to individual or from society to society, but also from time to time within the same society and by the same individual. In Nigeria attention has usually been drawn to the differing responses of the Igbo, the Yoruba and the 'HausaFulani' to indirect rule. In Kenya, the Gikuyu accepted western innova› tions, modifying these to suit themselves while many of their neighbours tended to adopt the opposite stance.
One can, therefore, subscribe to the view that change as such was not new to colonial Africa and that there is no African society which was not affected to an appreciable extent by European contact or which simply withered before it. One must also concede that with colonial rule the ideology of change came to be consciously embraced by the rulers of Africa and their would-be friends. Even those colonial officials who were strongly committed to the policy and practice of indirect rule, with its emphasis on the preservation of traditional institutions and values, still recognized the need for change. Indeed under indirect rule indigenous institutions and rulers were expected to serve as media for introducing reform in measured doses and in ways acceptable to the colonial authority. Every colonial administration saw change as the only way of modernizing Africa and fitting her into the orbit of the West to the latter's advantage. The indigenous elites have patronized change as a way of getting Africa on to her feet and making her states equal members of the community of nations.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.699, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The social repercussions of colonial rule: the new social structures', 'section_title': 'The rise of new organizations', 'content': "As already mentioned, the social effects of foreign rule were far from uniform throughout the continent. With respect to the spread of education, the triumph of the new economic forces, the expansion of urbanization and therefore the rise of the new elites, West Africa would appear to have witnessed the greatest advances, followed by Egypt and the Maghrib, South Africa, East Africa and Central Africa. If, on the other hand, in this matter we compared the colonial blocks rather than geographical regions, we discover that greater changes took place in the British territories, followed by Belgian- and French-ruled Africa with Portuguese Africa limping far behind. And even among the British territories, there was also a differential impact. The British colonies where substantial transforma- tions were registered included Egypt, Gold Coast, Nigeria, Uganda and Sierra Leone, with Kenya and the Rhodesias (now Zambia and Zimbabwe) coming after. And if we take individual colonies we discover that more changes took place in the southern than in the northern parts of Gold Coast and Nigeria. In Francophone Africa, on the other hand, the West African colonies would come first, followed by the North African colonies and then French Equatorial Africa. Within French West Africa, Senegal and Dahomey (now Benin) led the way with the other colonies lagging rather far behind.
The fact was that the spread and impact of the forces of change were controlled by more factors than any colonial government or African group was in a position to master completely. First there was the question of the length and extent of contact which the particular territory or geographic region had enjoyed with Europe by the time colonial rule was imposed. West and Southern Africa had maintained fairly regular contact with Europe from the sixteenth century. By the beginning of the nineteenth century, therefore, quasi-urban conditions of life had come into existence at several points along the coast - at St Louis, Banjul, Accra, Lagos, the Oil River's ports, Luanda, and at the Cape. These provided good stepping stones for the forces of western education, western Christianity and western commerce to penetrate the interior. The east coast of the continent, on the other hand, came under sustained European contact only from about the 1870s.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.699, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}]

[{'id': 616, 'article_title': 'Conflict of Authorities at Cape Coast', 'full_section_title': 'Conflict of Authorities at Cape Coast', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1865#article-24', 'issue_date': '23_05_1865', 'content': 'Governor Pine, who has returned to England by this month's mail to give evidence before the Committee of the House of Commons, is either one of the most calumniated of men, or one of the most incompetent and unfit to rule. We have been compelled to allude from time to time to the discredit into which the Cape Coast Governor had fallen among the natives. The discontent of the Eastern Provinces has been very loudly expressed; and now we have an open conflict of powers at Cape Coast itself, where, if anywhere, it would be supposed that the authority of the Governor would be respected.

In addition to the very temperate and clever letter in another column signed "Gold Coast," we have quite a number of others, setting forth the alleged incompetency and discredit of the Governor and Government. They are none of them such as we choose to publish verbatim. Our work is the correction of abuses, and of all that impedes advancement, which includes necessarily the exposure of the former. But beyond this we do not care to go. We do not wish to crush a man beneath a heaped-up catalogue load of improprieties and errors—of flagrant and discrediting omissions and commissions. We have steadily refused to publish anything that had reference to other than what may be properly called the official life and acts of the authorities, although no Governor or other depositary of power, especially in such a place as Cape Coast, can be said to have any private life—because all he says and does must have influence either for good or for harm, either for the advancement of morality and good principles, or the reverse—either to increase or to decrease the prestige of the ruler or the judge. And a half-civilized people are generally very shrewd observers of what is wrong, although they may be very evil doers themselves.'}, {'id': 2633, 'article_title': "Gaboon River—The Cannibal 'Fans'", 'full_section_title': "Gaboon River—The Cannibal 'Fans'", 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/31_12_1873#article-8', 'issue_date': '31_12_1873', 'content': 'King George Pepple a large share of support, in his endeavours to introduce into his country a civilized form of government, and a civilized order of things in general—by studying to acquire such intimate knowledge of the customs, tastes, and modes of thought of the native chiefs, as will peculiarly qualify him to settle their mutual palavers in the interest of commerce, with facility and success, by equitably and yet firmly composing all commercial or other differences that may arise between these chiefs and British traders and residents; in fine, by making it his aim to promote alike British as well as native interests, he may justly deserve, and speedily win, the confidence, esteem, affection, and gratitude of all classes of the population, European and African, within the countries placed under his jurisdiction. We cordially welcome him among us, and pray that his Consulship may be characterized by tangible results of a beneficial nature to this portion of our Coast. It will, I doubt not, also interest you to learn that Captain Nicol, one of the official members of the Coomassie Expedition, also arrived here from Cape Coast, in quest of men to join the native troops proposed to be organized for that expedition. He has obtained from Jaja, of Opobo, about fifty-three men, whom he has taken to the seat of war per steamship Biafra. He has also entered into some negotiations with the King and chiefs of Bonny; and Prince Charles, Mr. John Jumbo (son of Oko Jumbo), and Mr. John Martin have been ordered by King George Pepple to go to Cape Coast or Accra with one hundred picked men, who have been drilled morning and evening gratuitously by Captain Hopkins (ex-Vice-Consul). It is understood that it is open to the Prince and Mr. Jumbo to remain at the Gold Coast at their discretion, or be recalled by the King, as circumstances may require. They will leave per steamship Liberia, by which also you will receive this letter. We hope this will lead to good in many ways.—Yours sincerely, A Votary of Civilization.'}, {'id': 5128, 'article_title': 'Death of Governor Young', 'full_section_title': 'Death of Governor Young', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1885#article-20', 'issue_date': '01_06_1885', 'content': 'Intelligence has lately reached London of the death of Sir William Alexander George Young, Governor of the Gold Coast, which occurred on the 25th of April, at Accra, Gold Coast Colony. The deceased was a son of the late Mr. William Young, a captain in the Royal Marines, and was born in 1827. He was formerly in the Royal Navy, and served as Naval Secretary to several flag officers. Mr. Young was present during the operations in the Baltic in the Russian war of 1855-56. In 1856 he acted as Secretary to the North American Boundary Commission, and in 1859 he was appointed Colonial Secretary and Auditor of British Columbia. He was nominated Colonial Secretary of Vancouver Island in 1864, Administrator of the Government of Vancouver Island in 1866, and was afterwards successively Colonial Secretary of British Columbia, Assistant Colonial Secretary of Jamaica, Acting Colonial Secretary and Administrator of the Government of Jamaica, Government Secretary of British Guiana, Lieutenant-Governor of British Guiana, Administrator of the Government of Trinidad, and Acting Governor of the Gold Coast. He was nominated a Companion of the Order of St. Michael and St. George in 1877. He married, in 1858, Cecilia, daughter of Captain Cowan, and niece of the late Sir James Douglas, Governor of British Columbia.'}, {'id': 5193, 'article_title': 'LAGOS NEWS TO JULY 6TH', 'full_section_title': 'LAGOS NEWS TO JULY 6TH', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1885#article-6', 'issue_date': '01_09_1885', 'content': "On Tuesday, the 30th, Mrs. Payne and her two nieces, Misses Victoria and Stella Davies, embarked, per mail steamer Teneriffe, for Sierra Leone, on a visit. They were accompanied on their way by many of their friends, and were joined at the Wharf by Mr. Consul Hood, and Miss Campbell, and Mr. C. J. George, and others. The Benito left at 4 p.m., and some of the party went with them to the beach, and returned in Mr. Hood's boat, but Captain Davies and Mr. Registrar Payne, with Mesdames Ed. Davies and M. Davies and Mrs. Reffle, accompanied them over the Bar.

July 2nd, Messrs. Pagan, Surveyor-General, and Captain Potter, of the s.s. Ekuro, embarked per Nubia for Accra.

July 3rd, the steamer Sherbro arrived from England, and it is rumoured that it is likely our present Lieutenant-Governor would be appointed Governor-in-Chief of the Gold Coast Colony. We hope it will be so, for he deserves it, having had sufficient experience to justify the appointment."}, {'id': 6334, 'article_title': 'Banquet to Governor Carter at Liverpool', 'full_section_title': 'Banquet to Governor Carter at Liverpool', 'last_edit_date': '06-16-1893', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_07_1893#article-5', 'issue_date': '03_07_1893', 'content': 'Mr. F. Henderson (vice-president of the Chamber) briefly proposed the toast of “Our other Guests.”

Sir A. W. L. Hemming, K.C.M.G., of the Colonial Office, in responding, said he was not prepared to say his department never made mistakes, but he was sure no error had been committed in sending Sir Gilbert Carter to Lagos.

His Excellency Sir Francis Fleming, K.C.M.G., also responded, and said that there was one consolation to those who had to spend their lives in regions far away from the land of their birth, and that was that when they did return they would be welcomed by those at home who took an interest in the land in which they laboured. He had been in many colonial positions, but in no place did he find more interesting work to do than in the West African Settlements. A governor in West Africa had to act in the threefold capacity of administrator, in the ordinary sense of the word, as arbitrator and adviser to the native chiefs, and as diplomatist in regard to those foreign powers who were making their way into certain portions of the country. In the performance of those duties a governor required all the tact and ability he could command, and these had been admirably displayed by Governor Carter in his recent experiences.

Captain Lugard also responded to the toast, and said that England had been unfortunate in not obtaining the opinions of experts with regard to the wealth and possibilities of her colonies.

Mr. A. L. Jones, who was received with a great deal of applause, proposed “The Members of Parliament,” mentioning the names of the late Mr. Whitley, the late Mr. Cross, and Mr. Lawrence as gentlemen who had given their especial assistance in Parliament in regard to West Africa.

Mr. Lawrence, in responding, said no matter what their opinions might be as to the best method of keeping the empire united, they were quite unanimous as to the necessity of its extension.—Mr. Royden also responded, and said he believed that they were all animated by the desire of promoting their country’s best interests.—Sir Edward R. Russell also responded.

Mr. E. Lawrence, J.P., proposed the “African Trade,” and this was responded to by Mr. J. Holt, and a vote of thanks to the chairman brought the proceedings to a close.'}]
